The  Lao  PDR  has  abundant  natural  resources  and  a  small 
population, of which over 80% is dependent on agriculture for their 
livelihood. Significant numbers of indigenous peoples from a wide 
range of linguistic groups live in upland areas to the north and in 
the southern part of the Lao PDR along the border with Viet Nam. 
They  forge  their  predominantly  subsistence  livelihoods  from 
rotational  cropping,  which  incorporates  a  heavy  dependence  on 
the natural forest and water resources. The incidence of poverty in 
these areas is over 60%, and is highest among ethnic groups. 
 
The institutional and legal framework for sustainable and equitable 
management of agriculture and natural resources (ANR) is weak. 
This is evident in the ambiguity of policies and legislation, as well 
as  inadequate  professional  and  technically  trained  staff  and

Capacity  building  activities  will  lead  to  improved  national  and

informed  decisions  about 
investment  in  the  sector  (public,  private,  and  foreign  direct

benefits  to  be  derived  from  this  external  source  of  development 
capital.  As  the  scale  of  land  concessions  is  large  in  relation  to 
existing  crop  areas  and  will  only  increase  during  the  life  of  the 
Project,  project  benefits  can  be  expected  to  be  large  in  scale, 
geographically dispersed, and affect all the rural population. 
 
Benefits  from  the  subproject  investments  will  include  increased 
agricultural  productivity  from  irrigation  and  support  of  technical 
extension  services.  Increased  commercialization  will  result  from 
rural  road  rehabilitation  and  strengthening  the  linkages  between 
producers and domestic/subregional markets. Economically viable 
subprojects  will  contribute  to  local  and  national  food  security, 
address 
issues  of  climate  change,  and  promote  regional 
integration. Overall, the integrity of the natural resource base will 
be  maintained  and  the  process  of  managing  competing  interests 
in their use will be rationalized. 
 
The  number  of  beneficiaries  will  be  substantial,  as  concession 
land areas affected comprise about half the total cropped area of 
the provinces. The geographical dispersion of the subprojects and 
targeting  of  investments  in  border  areas  mean  that  beneficiaries 
will include the ethnic groups residing in upland areas. Women will 
also be targeted beneficiaries. 
 
The  main  institutional  risk  to  the  Project  lies  in  potential  conflict 
between  relatively  autonomous  provinces  (that  have  enjoyed 
considerable latitude in the award of land concessions) and state 
agencies trying to standardize and rationalize the issuance of land 
concessions  (and  prevent  illegal  issuance).  This  risk  has  been 
mitigated  by  involving  high-level  political  authority  from  the 
provinces in the project design process, and obtaining widespread 
commitment  to  reforming  the  land  concessions’  award  system. 
Greater  clarity 
increased 
publication  of  land  concessions  awards  reduce  the  governance 
risks associated with large-scale land allocations. 
 
A  second  risk  concerns  the  allocation  of  funds  for  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) of  rural infrastructure rehabilitated under the 
Project.  This  is  a  systemic  and  ongoing  issue,  as  cash-limited 
provincial  authorities  are  responsible  for  maintenance  of  state 
assets but receive few resources from the national budget to carry 
out  routine  and  periodic  maintenance.  This  issue  has  been 
mitigated  by  (i)  requiring  provinces  in  which  subprojects  are 
located  to  sign  formal  commitments  to  meet  O&M  expenses, 
(ii) the  Government  providing  a  specific  assurance  that  it  will

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
Asian  Development  Fund  grant  to  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  for  the 
Sustainable Natural Resource Management and Productivity Enhancement Project, and (ii) the 
proposed administration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of a grant to be provided by the 
International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). The report also describes the proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Sustainable  Natural  Resource  Management  and  Productivity 
Enhancement and if the Board approves the proposed grant and administration of the grant, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
The Lao PDR is a sparsely populated, mostly mountainous country, with limited arable 
land (estimated at about 10% of its total area). The population depends primarily on agriculture 
(estimated  80%  of  the  labor  force),  contributing  42%  of  the  gross  domestic  product,  with  rice 
farming  alone  accounting  for  39%  of  the  agricultural  gross  domestic  product.1 Sector  growth 
rates  were  maintained  at  about  5%  per  year  from  1996  to  2000,  but  slowed  to  about  3%  per 
year thereafter as restrictions on logging were introduced. Rice accounts for about 80% of the 
cultivated  area—comprising  about  68,000  hectares  (ha)  of  irrigated  production,  620,000  ha  of 
rain-fed  paddies,  and  108,000  ha  of  upland  rice;  collectively,  these  account  for  the  bulk  of 
domestic food production. 2 
 
3. 
At  the  household  level,  food  security  is  mainly  women’s  responsibility.  Livestock  is  a 
significant  contributor  to  sector  output  as  well  as  household  incomes  and  nutrition.  Growth  in 
agricultural  production  has  been  impressive  since  the  mid-1990s,  partly  stimulated  by  reforms 
supported by ADB through two program loans and by a rapid expansion of the irrigated area3. 
From 1995 to 2005, rice production increased from 1.4 million tons to 2.4 million tons, enabling 
the country to achieve broad national self-sufficiency in 2000. From 1992 to 2003, the incidence 
of  poverty  declined  from  46%  to  33%.4 Agriculture  is  central  to  both  individual  livelihoods  and 
provincial  economies  in  the  proposed  project  area—covering  40 districts  that  constitute  the 
provinces  of  Attapeu,  Champassak,  Salavane,  Savannakhet,  and  Sekong,  and  located  in  the 
south  of  the  country.5 Of  the  total  population  of  1.96  million,  rural  poverty  is  high  in  half  the 
districts.6 Within  the  “poor”  districts,  60%  of  the  villages  are  considered  poor  (Supplementary 
Appendix A). The incidence of poverty is highest among upland ethnic groups. 
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

4. 
The  agriculture  and  natural  resources  (ANR)  sector  is  characterized  by  low  levels  of 
productivity,  poor  agricultural  and  marketing  skills,  limited  market  access,  low  use  of  water

(Appendix  2).  Weak  governance  and  deficiencies  in  the  state’s  ability  to  achieve  planned 
objectives are notable. The institutional framework for sustainable and equitable management of 
ANR  is  weak,  manifest  in  ambiguous  policies  and  legislation,  and  inadequate  strengths  in 
professional and technically trained staff and facilities. At the provincial and district levels, where 
most of the ANR management decisions are taken, there is a deficit of expertise and facilities. 
The situation is exacerbated because of budgetary constraints (sufficient to meet staff salaries 
but insufficient for operational and development activities). There is only limited formal credit for 
ANR,  forcing  most  farmers  to  depend  on  more  expensive  informal  credit.  While  a  few  farmer 
organizations exist, farmer and water users associations are generally new, institutionally weak, 
unrepresentative  of  the  poorest  and  of  women,  and  generally  inexperienced  to  undertake  the 
functions  they  are  intended  to  perform.  Overall,  the  development  opportunity  is  to  address 
institutional  weakness  in  natural  resources  management  and  (simultaneously)  to  invest  in 
increasing sector productivity. 
 
5. 
The  most  obvious  manifestation  of  this  institutional  weakness  is  in  relation  to  natural 
resources  management—especially  land-use  management.  In  the  past  4–5  years,  growing 
demand  from  neighboring  countries  for  agricultural  commodities  has  attracted  investors  to  the 
Lao PDR either through contract farming to source agricultural commodities for processing, or 
through externally financed direct investment in plantations (e.g., concessions for rubber, sugar, 
cassava,  and  trees  for  pulp)  usually  with  foreign  expertise.  The  country  has  seen  a  major 
increase  in  foreign  direct  investment,  which  has  resulted  in  unprecedented  demand  for  large 
areas  of  agricultural  and  forest  land.  Concessions  were  being  granted  on  long  leases  at  very 
low  annual  rentals  ($5–$10  per  ha  per  year  for  50  years  was  not  uncommon),  with  no  proper 
financial  or  economic  appraisal  and  no  social  and  environmental  safeguards  in  place.  In  an 
attempt to contain this situation, the Government imposed a 1-year moratorium in May 2007 on 
the  granting  of  concessions  in  excess  of  100  ha  by  provinces.  However,  the  lack  of 
transparency of land transactions and inconsistencies in practice across provinces and between 
agencies has continued (despite the establishment of the National Land Management Authority 
under  the  Prime  Minister’s  Office).  Overall,  the  land  issue  has  exposed  confusion  in 
administrative  and  technical  processes,  and  conflicts  between  the  interests  of  the  state  in 
ensuring sustainable patterns of land use to maximize growth and ensure its sustainability, and 
(relatively autonomous) provincial administrations. While FDI should have positive impacts—in 
terms  of  capital,  technology,  and  skills  flows—it  is  likely  that  many  such  investments  will  be 
environmentally  damaging  (through  short-term  exploitation  or  longer-term  neglect),  non-
transparent  (mainly  benefiting  foreign  and  non-poor  domestic  interests  and  excluding  women 
and ethnic groups), and economically sub-optimal (in terms of adding to domestic employment 
and incomes). 
 
6. 
The security of smallholder tenure to and use of land and forest resources has an impact 
on the type and variety of crops that households are willing to plant. Consequently, it affects the 
poverty  status  of  communities  and  social  equity  (including  gender  and  ethnic  dimensions). 
There is a need to define more clearly and formalize rights of land access and use. While most 
of the forest area is classified as production forest, conservation forests (or national biodiversity 
conservation areas) and protection forests are delineated on maps, but actual demarcation has 
yet  to  take  place  on  the  ground.  This  lack  of  physical  demarcation  compromises  protection 
policy  and  makes  these  areas  vulnerable  to  encroachment,  leading  to  deforestation  and 
denudation.  Over  the  past  few  decades,  deforestation  has  been  severe  because  of  illegal 
logging, shifting cultivation, and encroachment. This destruction not only represents the loss of 
potentially productive assets, but also results in increased emission of substantial quantities of 
carbon dioxide. 

  

 

3

 
7. 
The other systemic ANR sector problem is low productivity. Factor productivity in the Lao 
PDR is low by the standards of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), and the 
recent achievement of broad national self-sufficiency in rice can only be maintained if gains in 
agricultural  productivity  can  be  ensured.  Poverty  is  highest  in  the  more  rugged  upland  areas 
where  traditional  shifting  cultivation  provides  subsistence  existence,  complemented  with  the 
extraction  of  non-timber  forest  products.  There  is  a  need  to  address  food  insecurity  and 
malnutrition, especially where the road network is underdeveloped. A move to more sustainable 
forms of agriculture in the upland environment (away from rice-based “slash and burn” systems) 
needs  to  be  complemented  through  potential  development  initiatives  that  can  contribute  to 
improving the incomes of communities and households (mainly populated by ethnic groups). In 
addition, enhanced focus on improving productivity in the lowland environment (where the larger 
number of poor households is found) needs to ensure sustainable use of natural resources. In 
the  lowlands,  there  is  also  a  fundamental  need  to  promote  ANR  sector  transition.  This  would 
(i) encourage  diversification  (into  new  crops  and  products,  e.g.,  niche  products,  livestock, 
coffee); (ii) promote value addition (through improved on- and off-farm processing, better post-
harvest  technology,  etc.);  and  (iii)  support  intensification  (e.g.,  through  new  crop  varieties)  to 
raise yields. The challenge exists to integrate more remote and hitherto neglected communities 
into the market economy with more commercial yet sustainable agricultural production systems. 
 

1. 

Lessons 

8. 
In 2005, a sector assistance program evaluation concluded that the contribution of ADB-
financed  investment  projects  to  the  performance  of  the  ANR  sector  had  been  limited.  It 
recommended  that  ADB  activities  in  the  ANR  sector  should  be  more  selective  and  focused  in 
terms  of  composition  and  spread,  and  should  take  into  account  government  priorities,  the 
division  of  roles  and  responsibilities  among  development  partners,  past  performance  of  ADB 
operations, identified lessons, and ADB’s comparative advantage and skills mix requirements. It 
also  recommended  that  the  future  approach  should  include  using  existing  aid  coordination 
channels  more  effectively  to  (i)  share  experience  and  knowledge,  (ii)  find  solutions  to  binding 
constraints  facing  the  ANR  sector,  and  (iii)  develop  replicable  approaches  that  can  provide 
greater benefits countrywide.7 These features are embedded in the project design. In addition, 
the  experience  of  designing  the  Forest  Plantation  Development  Project  demonstrated  the 
importance  of  working  within  existing  structures,  of  including  measures  to  improve  sector 
governance acceptable to policy makers, and of establishing a project scope that would prove 
feasible to implement within the country context, to move the governance agenda forward.8 
 
9. 
Experience  gained  by  IFAD  has  demonstrated  that  rural  development  requires 
coordinated  investment  in  several  sectors  to  have  a  significant  and  sustainable  poverty 
reduction  impact.  Among  the  main  lessons  from  past  IFAD  investments  are  (i)  focus  on 
strengthening  coordination  of  multisector  interventions  at  the  provincial  level  while  developing 
the  implementation  capacity  of  existing  line  agencies;  (ii)  promotion  of  decentralized  decision-
making  processes  of  the  government  system  to  ensure  institutional  sustainability;  (iii)  building 
capacity  at  the  grassroots  level  (villages  and  producer  associations)  as  it  represents  the 
foundation  of  successful  rural  poverty  reduction  initiatives;  (iv)  prioritizing  public  investment  in 
rural infrastructure targeted at upland and disadvantaged areas to reduce marginalization; and 
(v)  establishing  arrangements  for  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  and  developing  policy  on 
beneficiary contribution to rural infrastructure investments.

2. 

Government Policy 

10. 
The Government’s guiding document is the Sixth National Socio Economic Development 
Plan  (2006–2010).9 The  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  has  translated  its  content 
into specific targets and objectives outlining four overall objectives to be achieved through the 
implementation  of  13  measures  (Appendix  3).  The  four  strategic  objectives  for  the  sector  are 
(i) increased  food  production  and  security 10 —annual  food  production  equivalent  to  3.3 
million tons of rice increasing national average consumption to 350 kilograms (kg) per head per 
year (including poor districts) together with other targets for protein; (ii) increased  production 
of  materials  for  agro-processing—directed  at  domestic  processing  to  allow  agriculture  and 
forestry exports to increase to 30% of the value of exports ($1 billion by 2010); (iii) stabilization 
of shifting cultivation—the main strategy of poverty reduction in the 47 poorest districts, while 
providing for environmental protection; and (iv) sustainable  forest  management—to increase 
forest  cover  from  42%  to  53%  (12 million  hectares  by  2010)  with  commercial  plantations.  The 
13 measures  have  been  developed  to  give  effect  to  these  overall  objectives,  using  the 
Government’s budget and donor support (Appendix 4).11 
 

3. 

ADB Strategy for the Lao PDR 

11. 
ADB’s country strategy and program 2007–2011 aims to promote pro-poor, sustainable 
growth led by the private sector by improving policies and institutional capacity to support broad-
based,  private  sector-led  growth. 12  It  proposes  to  support  building  a  legal  and  regulatory 
framework and developing capacity in sectors and subsectors specifically identifying agriculture. 
The strategy supports greater involvement of civil society and mass organizations in the delivery 
of  agriculture  and  basic  social  services.  Support  will  be  provided  to  private  business 
associations to improve their ability to network, develop business skills, and advocate on behalf 
of  their  membership—expanding  livelihood  opportunities  for  rural  women  as  well  as  men  in 
commercial  agriculture  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  development.  Previous  ADB 
support  in  the  ANR  sector  has  been  catalytic  in  facilitating  private  sector  development, 
e.g., through  the  Northern  Region  Development  Strategy. 13  ADB  supports  increased  donor 
harmonization  within  the  framework  of  the  Paris  Declaration  (and  the  Vientiane  Declaration  of 
2006)  and  participates  in  the  Joint  Working  Group  on  Agriculture  and  Natural  Resources,  co-
chaired by MAF. 
 
12. 
IFAD  was  chosen  as  a  co-financier,  given  the  similarity  of  its  goals  and  objectives  to 
those  of  ADB  in  agriculture  and  rural  development  and  the  complementarity  of  approaches  in 
the proposed southern provinces. IFAD’s mandate is rural poverty reduction, and it has a record 
in  community  empowerment,  improving  the  livelihoods  of  the  poor,  and  investment  in  small-
scale infrastructure. As donor assistance has tended to be scattered, diverse, and limited in the 
southern Lao PDR, the Government proposed that ADB collaborate with IFAD in a harmonized 
manner.  The  Government  will  actively  manage  and  coordinate  activities,  and  ADB  and  IFAD 
under  this  partnership  will  facilitate  further  harmonization  and  alignment  of  development 
planning in the provinces to be covered under the Project.

4. 

Project Rationale 

13. 
As FDI is likely to be the main source of investment in the sector in the immediate future 
(domestic  capital  formation  is  low,  and  ANR  sector  enterprises  are  predominantly  small  and 
medium-sized  enterprises),  the  Government  has  an  interest  in  managing  FDI  to  ensure  that 
potentially beneficial aspects are realized and that harmful elements are avoided. In pursuit of 
food security and developing smallholders’ incomes, there is a need to strengthen the capacity 
of the respective line agencies to assess investment proposals, monitor and enforce approved 
investments’  compliance  with  law  and  their  contractual  and  license  conditions,  and  not 
compromise  the  integrity  of  natural  resources.  This  can  be  accomplished  through  appropriate 
land suitability assessment, classification, zoning, and ground demarcation of various categories 
of  forests  and  agricultural  land.  This  is  best  facilitated  by  building  capacities  of  the  institutions 
concerned  at  the  provincial  level,  supported  by  enhanced  capacity  at  the  national  level,  in 
screening  and  appraisal  techniques  that  include  economic  feasibility,  social  acceptability,  and 
environmental  stability  as  formal  approval  requirements.  Supporting  associated investments  in 
land-based public projects, upon which such processes can be applied, constructs a framework 
of  “learning  by  doing”.  It  also  ensures  a  direct  impact  on  sector  productivity  as  subproject 
investments  will  address  a  range  of  sector  objectives  (including  agriculture  commercialization, 
natural resource protection, and food security). 
 
The Project is consistent with ADB’s long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 
14. 
2020) for Lao PDR in promoting environmentally sustainable growth based on natural resources 
protection. 14  Economic  growth  will  be  inclusive,  as  resource  protection  disproportionately 
benefits  the  poorest,  and  subproject  investment  selection  criteria  will  ensure  targeting  of 
benefits.  ADB’s  strategy  focuses  on  two  key  drivers  of  change:  (i)  good  governance,  and  (ii) 
capacity development and formation of partnerships (e.g., with IFAD). Rural infrastructure also 
figures significantly in project design, in accordance with one of ADB’s core specializations. In 
addition,  the  Project  exploits  regional  integration  possibilities,  e.g.,  by  linking  with  Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS) based initiatives, including the East–West Economic Corridor. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

15. 
The project impact will be more efficient and sustainable natural resource management 
and  higher  sector  productivity.  The  project  outcome  will  be  enhanced  institutional  capacity  at 
national  and  provincial  levels  to  manage  natural  resource  utilization  in  a  sustainable  manner. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B. 

Outputs 

16. 
The  Project  will  generate  three  main  outputs:  (i)  capacity  building  for  agriculture  and 
natural resource sector management, (ii) investment in resource management and productivity 
enhancement, and (iii) efficient project management. 
 

1.

been  completed  (Supplementary  Appendix  B).  Prior  to  initiating  capacity  building  activities,  a

opportunities available to local livelihood systems. The technical expertise proposed under the 
subcomponent will respond to such challenges during implementation as required. 
 

2. 

Investment in Resource Management and Productivity Enhancement 

22. 
The  capacity  building  activities  in  component  1  will  have  equipped  decision-making 
agencies  with  the  skills  to  identify,  prioritize,  and  appraise  investments.  Applying  the 
strengthened capacities, an associated program of subproject investments will be implemented. 
These investments (beginning in year 2 of the Project, and once capacity building has begun) 
will contribute to meeting the Government’s overall objectives of the ANR sector—food security 
and poverty reduction; sector transition (intensification, diversification, value addition) and rural 
commercialization; and sustainability of natural resource utilization.17 
 
23. 
Small-  and  medium-sized  subprojects  identified  for  project  financing  will  replicate  or 
expand  previously  implemented  development  initiatives  in  similar  agro-ecological  zones  to 
extend  or  widen  the  benefit  to  local  communities.  The  process  will  comprise  district 
identification, provincial technical ratification and prioritization, and national review and approval, 
followed  by  provincial  implementation  and  management.  Evaluation  of  these  publicly  funded 
investments  will  require  an  appraisal  process  that  facilitates  incorporation  of  social  and 
environmental safeguards, in addition to technical and economic feasibility analyses. While food 
security  and  poverty  reduction  will  be  the  focus  in  the  upland  areas,  to  enhance  overall  food 
security,  the  strategy  in  the  lowlands  will  be  to  promote  integration  with  regional  markets  and 
enhance smallholder participation in them.  
 
24. 
Subproject design will be carried out incorporating social and environmental safeguards 
and other social and gender development considerations. Subprojects will be formulated at the 
district  level,  using  demand-based  procedures  including  a  comprehensive  needs  assessment 
with  guidance  from  the  provinces,  specified  by  the  Project.  The  target  group  for  subproject

design  includes  (i)  poor  farming  households  in  lowland  areas  that  lack  market  opportunities, 
have limited marketable surpluses, and lack secure land tenure; and (ii) poor farmers in upland 
areas  whose  livelihoods  are  threatened  by  insecure  land  tenure,  limited  agricultural  land  and 
awareness of their rights to forest products, lack of access to markets, and low levels of literacy. 
Specific attention will ensure that design considerations cater to the priorities of ethnic groups 
and women. 
 
25. 
To  be  eligible  for  funding  under  the  Project,  subprojects  must  be  able  to  demonstrate 
their  contribution  to  the  Government’s  sector  development  plans,  to  improving  agricultural 
productivity, and to contribute to poverty reduction. They must also be technically sustainable, 
particularly in respect of O&M for infrastructure; compliant with environmental regulations; and 
conform  to  regulatory  requirements  for  agriculture  and  commerce.  They  must  have  no 
significant  resettlement  or  land  compensation  implications  that  cannot  be  mitigated,  and 
potential beneficiaries must confirm the subproject as a priority investment following community 
consultation. Subprojects that can exploit GMS features (including the East–West Corridor and 
the  Biodiversity  Conservation  Initiative)  and  those  that  deal  with  climate  change  issues  (and 
could  access  the  Clean  Development  Mechanism  and  the  Climate  Change  Fund)  will  be 
encouraged.  Eligible  subprojects  will  include  rural  infrastructure  (rehabilitation  of  feeder  roads, 
access  tracks,  and  construction/rehabilitation  of  small-  and  medium-scale  irrigation);  specific 
purpose  extension  initiatives;  piloting  grain  storage;  and  handling  equipment  using  advanced 
post-harvest handling technologies.18 Three categories of subprojects are anticipated: (i) those 
contributing  primarily  to  commercialization  of  agriculture,  (ii)  those  contributing  to  poverty 
reduction,  and  (iii)  those  contributing  primarily  to  natural  resource  management.  To  assure  a 
balance  between  these  categories,  a  prioritized  ranking  mechanism  is  proposed  (Appendix  5 
and Supplementary Appendix C) to allow subproject proposals from each category to compete 
for  funding  approval.  Subproject  proposals  to  be  implemented  in  priority  poor  districts 
(Supplementary Appendix D) will receive an additional  weighting to elevate their priority in the 
selection process. 
 

3. 

Project Management 

26. 
The Project has a strong capacity building focus, which must be effectively managed at 
the  national  level  to  ensure  consistency  of  application.  Similarly,  the  implementation  of  6–13 
subprojects  in  each  province,  all  identified  using  bottom-up  procedures  with  possible 
multiagency  implementation,  will  demand  a  high  level  of  project  management  skills.  The 
component will provide technical support for this process while providing resources to establish 
and operate a management structure at both national and provincial levels. At national level, the 
component will establish a small project coordination office (PCO) within MAF’s DOP, providing 
resources to operate the facility with vehicles, equipment, and an operating budget as well as 
international  and  national  training  expertise.  Provincial  project  offices  (PPOs)  will  be  provided 
office equipment and vehicles, together with operating budgets and incremental national staff, to 
support project management and selection and screening of subprojects. 
 
C. 

Special Features 

One significant special feature of the Project is support to devolution of responsibility for 
27. 
management of the country’s natural resources to provincial and district levels. With devolution 
of land management to lower echelons of government, there is a need to enable local levels to 
make decisions regarding land allocation. The incorporation of safeguard considerations in this 
decision-making process is critical to the protection of livelihood sources for rural communities 
and maintaining the environmental integrity of the area. 

 

                                                 
18 Potential subprojects might also include those contributing to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. 

  

 

9

The  Project  is  unique  as  it  will  develop  provincial  capacity  to  determine  land  suitability 
28. 
and  assess  the  impact  from  potential  investments,  as  well  as  initiate  public  disclosure  of 
concessions  awards.  As  part  of  this  initiative,  an  assessment  of  existing  concessions  will  be 
carried out to prepare a detailed database of these concessions and post non-commercial terms 
of  such  information  on  a  public  website.  In  addition,  commercial  terms  and  conditions  of  such 
concessions  will  be  recorded  in  a  confidential  database  for  monitoring  compliance  of  the 
concessionaire  with  such  terms  and  conditions,  and  to  facilitate  administration  of  the 
Government’s commitments in the concessions. 
 
29. 
An  important  aspect  in  the  selection  of  subprojects  will  be  their  key  strategic  impact, 
maximized  through  rigorous  local  contextual  selection  and  design  processes.  As  multiple 
subproject  proposals  are  anticipated,  a  ranking  mechanism  is  proposed  to  be  applied  in  the 
provinces prior to their submission for final approval at the central level. The process will enable 
subprojects  with  different  technical  foci  and  cost  structures  to  be  compared,  allowing  for 
prioritization  of  investments.  Strategic  impact  on  subregional  integration  will  be  achieved 
through rural roads opening up border areas, and opportunities to access agriculture skills and 
technology from neighboring provinces in Viet Nam will be explored. 
 
30. 
In  facilitating  effective  implementation,  the  expertise  of  the  Core  Environment  Program 
and  Biodiversity  Conservation  Corridors  Initiative  will  be  utilized  for  (i)  transfer  of  skills  and 
capacity  building  activities  related  to  land-use  planning  approaches  and  related  spatial 
surveying and analysis techniques; (ii) distillation of lessons and packaging of scalable impacts 
from  pilot  sites  to  other  provinces  targeted  under  this  Project;  (iii)  provision  of  hands-on  skills 
training  in  natural  resource  management  and  forest  and  ecosystem  restoration;  and  (iv) 
provision of  planning and technical input for greening of the East–West Economic Corridor.19

Financing Plan

It  is  proposed  that  ADB  provide  a  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $20  million 
equivalent from its Special Funds resources to finance 54.4% of the total project cost. IFAD will 
provide  a  grant  of  $15  million  to  finance  40.8%  of  the  project  cost.  The  Government  will 
contribute $1.775 million, accounting for 4.8%, to finance the total project cost, covering taxes 
and duties and salaries of seconded government staff (Table 2). The IFAD grant will be untied 
and  will  be  administered  by  ADB  following  the  Partial  Administration  Modality.  Conditions  and 
arrangements for IFAD cofinancing, to be confirmed through a written endorsement from IFAD, 
will be through a bilateral financing agreement to be negotiated between the Government and 
IFAD. A cofinancing agreement will be entered into by ADB and IFAD. Proceeds of the grants 
will be passed to the five participating provincial governments by the national government as a 
grant.

33. 
The Executing Agency (EA) for the proposed Project will be MAF’s DOP, responsible for 
overall  project  performance.  The  implementing  agencies  will  be  the  five  provincial  governors’ 
offices in participating provinces, with responsibility for coordinating implementation. 
 

1. 

Project Management 

34. 
The Project will be managed by a PCO to be established within MAF’s DOP. This office 
will  be  headed  by  a  full-time  national  project  director  assisted  by  a  full-time  national  project 
manager,  implementation  officer,  procurement  officer,  monitoring  and  evaluation  officer, 
administration  manager,  administration  assistant,  accountant,  and  secretarial  staff.  The  PCO 
will be responsible for day-to-day management of the Project under the direction of the national

project steering committee (NPSC). It will be responsible for (i) consolidating provincial annual 
workplans and budgets into the project workplans and procurement plan for submission to the 
Government,  ADB,  and  IFAD  on  an  annual  basis;  (ii)  overall  reporting  of  implementation 
progress to the Government and ADB and IFAD; (iii) financial management of the five advance 
project  accounts  and  the  PCO  project  advance  account  as  well  as  the  two  project  imprest 
accounts; (iv) preparing and submitting withdrawal applications through the EA to the Ministry of 
Finance  (MOF)  in  a  timely  manner;  (v)  developing  the  training  program  and  recruiting  local 
institutes  accordingly;  (vi)  procurement  and  management  of 
consultants  and 
(vii)  oversight  of  subproject 
performance-based  contracts 
implementation;  (viii)  maintaining  an  efficient  project  performance  monitoring  system  (PPMS); 
and (ix) providing secretariat services to the NPSC. The PCO will be guided by a NPSC chaired 
by a deputy minister of MAF; the vice chair will be elected from among the five participating vice 
governors  appointed  to  the  NPSC  and  rotated  annually.  It  will  comprise  representatives  from 
relevant national agencies including MAF, National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute, 
National Agriculture and Forestry Extension Service, MOF, Ministry of Planning and Investment, 
National  Land  Management  Authority  (NLMA)  of  the  PCO,  and  WREA.  The  NPSC  will  meet 
biannually  or  as  required  to  achieve  interagency  coordination  and  overall  implementation 
efficiency. 
 
35. 
At  the  provincial  level,  PPOs  will  be  established  and  will  be  responsible  for 
implementation.20 The project office is to be established in one of the existing line agencies to 
avoid incurring overhead costs for establishment of new offices. Staff appointments to PPOs will 
include a part full-time provincial project director assisted by a full-time implementation officer, 
administration manager, accountant, and a secretary-cum-administration assistant. The staff will 
be nominated from MAF, Ministry of Planning and Investment, and MOF in consultation with the 
provincial  governor.  For  day-to-day  management,  PPOs  will  respond  to  the  PCO  for  reporting 
and  other  implementation  matters  and  will  be  responsible  for  (i)  awareness  raising  and 
dissemination  of  information  about  the  Project;  (ii)  supervising  subproject  identification;  (iii) 
supporting  preparation  of  subproject  proposals;  (iv)  reviewing  and  approving  proposals  to 
proceed to feasibility study; (v) supporting preparation of feasibility studies, including safeguards 
compliance analysis;  (vi)  reviewing  feasibility  studies,  then prioritizing  them  for  presentation  to 
national  level;  (vii)  subproject  implementation  management;  (viii)  monitoring  the  impact  from 
subprojects; (ix) attending to progress and financial reporting requirements of the Project; and 
(x) secretarial services to the provincial coordination committees (PCCs). PPOs will be guided 
by  PCCs  to  be  established  in  participating  provinces,  chaired  by  the  provincial  vice  governor 
(the provincial representative on NPSC). The composition of PCCs will mirror that of the NPSC, 
with  multisector  representation.  PCCs  will  meet  on  a  quarterly  basis  or  as  required  to  provide 
guidance  on  overall  implementation  and  approve  the  prioritized  list  of  subprojects  for 
consideration at national level. 
 

2. 

Subproject Formulation, Identification, Prioritization, and Approval 

36. 
The process of formulation, identification, prioritization, and approval of subprojects will 
ensure  that  (i)  subprojects  reflect  genuine  stakeholder  demand;  (ii)  access  to  grant  funds  is 
rigorously  screened;  and  (iii)  subprojects  have  sound  technical,  commercial,  social,  and 
environmental  prospects.  All  processes  will  be  carried  out  by  existing  institutional  structures, 
supported by project staff and TA provided under the Project. As a first step, campaigns will be 
conducted  in  all  districts  to  create  awareness  of  (i)  the  rules  and  guidelines  for  subproject 
formulation, (ii) the application process, (iii) screening criteria and the prioritization process, and

(iv)  the  implementation  process.  Support  for  the  preparation  of  potential  subproject  proposals 
will be encouraged from a range of stakeholders—including districts, community organizations, 
nongovernment  organizations,  line  agencies,  existing  rural  development  projects,  or  rural 
business  and  or  community  partnerships  involved  in  agricultural  development  initiatives.  The 
support  for  development  of  subprojects  will  be more  intense  in  priority  poor  districts,  including 
upland  areas.  Special  awareness  processes  will  be  designed  to  ensure  participation  by  all 
communities, including ethnic groups. 
 
Guidelines to assist identification of candidate subprojects will be prepared by the PCO 
37. 
and  disseminated  widely  throughout  participating  provinces.  District  authorities  will  screen 
candidate  subprojects  to  ensure  that  each  conforms  to  subproject  eligibility  criteria.  PPO  staff 
will  assist  the  district  offices  in  this process.  To  become  eligible  for  grant  funding,  subprojects 
must (i) be consistent with national agricultural development strategies; (ii) be based on proven 
technical  parameters  and 
the  participating 
provinces  or  other  areas  of  similar  agro-ecological  environs);  (iii)  have  a  significant  potential 
impact  on  poverty  reduction  (targeting  poor  households,  ethnic  groups,  and  women);  (iv)  be 
based on a demonstrated demand; and (v) have the potential to be financially and institutionally 
sustainable. 21  Non-eligibility  criteria  would  include  (i)  an  overlap  with  BCI  or  other  donor 
activities aimed at ANR management, (ii) having adverse impacts on the environment that could 
not  easily  be  mitigated,  and  (iii)  having  significant  resettlement  implications.  All  subprojects 
would be compliant with the safeguard policies of ADB, IFAD, and the Government.  
 
38. 
Candidate  subprojects  will  be  submitted  to  PPOs,  where  their  conformity  with  project 
criteria will be confirmed. Following this screening, subproject proposals will become eligible to 
receive support for the preparation of a more detailed feasibility study. A full feasibility study for 
each  candidate  subproject  will  be  carried  out  under  the  supervision  of  the  PPO  and  by  the 
relevant line agencies, in close consultation with the sponsors, and assisted by project-funded 
TA as required. As subproject proposals will be diverse, a prioritizing mechanism is proposed to 
enable  comparison.  To  ensure  that  disadvantaged  (priority  poor)  districts  receive  due 
consideration, a weighting will be applied in the case of poverty reduction category subprojects. 
PCOs  will  apply  these  criteria  to  candidate  subprojects  and  prepare  a  prioritized  list  of 
subprojects  for  consideration  by  PCCs.  After  priority  rankings  have  been  confirmed  by  PCCs, 
eligible subprojects will be submitted to the PCO for consideration. The prioritizing mechanism 
is in Appendix 5 and Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
39. 
The  PCO  will  confirm  the  prioritization  of  eligible  subprojects,  and  publish  these 
proposals  for  public  comments.  Following  this  disclosure,  the  proposals  will  be  referred  to  a 
Technical  Review  Committee  that  will  (i)  review  and  evaluate  subproject  feasibility  studies, 
(ii) reject  or  seek  amendments  to  subprojects  as  appropriate,  and  (iii)  prepare  summary 
investment  reports  for  consideration  by  the  NPSC.  Based  on  the  provincial  allocation  of  grant 
funds to participating provinces, the NPSC will approve subprojects to be implemented and the 
PCO will advise the provinces accordingly. Grant funds will be allocated in accordance with the 
costs  detailed  in  approved  subproject  feasibility  studies,  and  will  be  registered  as  committed 
funds in the financial management information system. 
 

3. 

Implementation 

40. 
The proposed Project will be implemented over a period of 6 years from 1 June 2009 to 
30 June 2015 (Appendix 7). About 45 medium-to-large subprojects (each valued at $100,000–

$500,000). An additional 25 smaller subprojects (from $20,000 - $100,000) will also be financed. 
Provinces have little experience in identifying and designing subprojects, and responsibility for 
implementation  will  be  spread  among  the  five  provinces.  Therefore,  capacity  building  and 
subproject  identification  and  design  will  take  place  within  the  first  year.  The  detailed  training 
program  will  be  developed  to  meet  the  needs  expressed  in  the  approved  subprojects.  As

year of implementation. Where subprojects require extension services and agricultural research 
inputs,  local  extension  and  agricultural  research  agencies  will  be  contracted  to  the  extent 
possible. Where availability of services is limited, national service providers (public and private) 
will  be  contracted  to  work  with  the  local  line  agency  to  deliver  services.  Performance-based 
contracts  will  be  used  to  ensure  that  payments  are  made  based  on  services  rendered  and 
incentives are in place for effective delivery. The final year of the Project will be spent ensuring 
that arrangements are in place to sustain subproject initiatives after completion. 
 

4. 

Procurement 

A  procurement  plan  is  outlined  in  Appendix  8,  with  indicative  contracts  to  be  awarded 
41. 
based  on  requirements  of  the  Project.  Prior  and  post  review  thresholds  were  discussed  and 
agreed with the EA, and are included in the plan. Procurement will mainly be undertaken by the 
PCO. Goods and works financed by ADB and IFAD will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines  (2007, as amended from time to time). Packages for works valued at 
less than $1 million or equivalent but more than $100,000 or equivalent, shall be procured using 
national  competitive  bidding  using  single-stage,  two-envelope  procedures.  For  works  below 
$100,000  equivalent,  shopping  procedures  may  be  used.  Goods  costing  less  than  $500,000 
equivalent but more than $100,000 shall be procured through national competitive bidding using 
single-stage,  one-envelope  procedures.  Smaller  packages  for  goods  valued  at  less  than 
$100,000  may  be  procured  through  shopping  procedures.  To  ensure  sustainability  and  to 
achieve the social objectives of the Project, procurement, specifications, and contract packaging 
of  selected  components  may  be  adapted  to  involve  local  communities  and  nongovernment 
organizations, to use more local knowledge and materials, and to use labor-intensive and other 
technologies. 
 

5. 

Consulting Services 

42. 
The  Project  will  require  three  kinds  of  consulting  services:  (i)  to  assist  the  PCO  with 
project  and  financial  management,  subproject  identification,  and  implementation;  (ii)  to  assist 
the  PCO  and  PPOs  in  technical  areas,  including  GIS,  information  management,  financial  and 
economic appraisal techniques; and (iii) to provide policy development support. Consultants will 
be  recruited  through  a  firm  using  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  (QCBS)  in  line  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) and the Project’s 
procurement plan (Appendix 8). Implementation management and technical consulting services 
will be recruited through a consulting firm using QCBS (80:20) with full technical proposals. The 
PCO  will  recruit  national  consultants  to  assist  in  the  preparation  of  feasibility  studies  for 
subprojects  from  national  firms  using  consultant’s  qualification  selection  (CQS)  with  the 
simplified  technical  proposal.  This  method  will  be  used  since  (i)  few  of  the  existing  national 
consultants  are  qualified,  (ii)  the  quality  of  the  firms’  output  will  be  critical  to  assessment  and 
mitigation of the subproject’s environmental and social impact, and (iii) recruitment time will be 
critical.  The  PCO  will  also  be  responsible  for  recruiting  national  consultants  to  provide 
supervision services for the implementation of approved subprojects. These consultants will be 
recruited  using  CQS  and  the  biodata  technical  proposal  since  they  will  be  hired  under  small 
packages of $200,000 or less, recruitment time is critical, and the small size of contracts does 

 

 14 

 

 

not justify the preparation and evaluation of competitive proposals. To support implementation 
and capacity building initiatives, the Project will fund a total of 722 person-months of consulting 
services  (84  person-months  international  and  638  person-months  national).  Outline  terms  of 
reference for consulting services are in Supplementary Appendix F. 
 

6. 

Anticorruption Policy 

43. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  EA.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance,  accountability,  and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt,  fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  relating  to  the  Project.  To  support  these 
efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the grant regulations 
and  the  bidding  documents  for  the  Project.  In  particular,  all  contracts  financed  by  ADB  in 
connection  with  the  Project  shall  include  provisions  specifying  the  right  of  ADB  to  audit  and 
examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  the  EA  and  all  contractors,  suppliers,  consultants,  and 
other service providers as they relate to the Project. 
 

7. 

Disbursement Arrangements 

44. 
To  expedite  disbursement,  the  Government  will  establish  two  first-generation  imprest 
accounts22 at  the  Bank  of  the  Lao  PDR—one  for  the  ADB  grant  and  the  other  for  the  IFAD 
grant—immediately  after  loan  effectiveness.  The  imprest  accounts  will  be  managed  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time) 
and detailed arrangements agreed by the Government, ADB and IFAD. These accounts will be 
managed by MOF. The maximum amount to be deposited in each of the imprest accounts will 
be  based  on  an  estimated  6  months  of  project  expenditure  to  be  funded  from  the  imprest 
accounts or a maximum of 10% of the ADB and IFAD grants, whichever is lower. Advance  of 
operational  costs  to  the  PCO  and  PPOs  will  be  based  on  approved  work  plans  and  budget 
schedules, and transferred to project advance accounts to be established at a commercial bank 
acceptable to the Government and ADB. Separate project advance accounts will be established 
for the ADB grant proceeds and the IFAD grant proceeds. The advance accounts shall have an 
initial  advance,  and  the  maximum  ceiling  is  equivalent  to  6  months  of  operating  expenditures. 
The advance accounts shall be opened with the equivalent of $50,000 for the PCO and $20,000 
for  each  of  the  five  provincial  advance  accounts,  and  will  be  reimbursed  using  procedures 
acceptable to ADB. Liquidation and replenishment of the project advance accounts for the PCO 
will be based on prior submission of full documentation to MOF through the EA (MAF). For the 
project  advance  accounts  of  PPOs,  liquidation  and  replenishment  will  be  based  on  prior 
submission of full documentation to the PCO for endorsement before submitting to MOF through 
the EA. The project advance accounts for IFAD grant proceeds will only be used for expenses 
related to supporting smallholder groups, including (i) training support to producer groups other 
than  the  Decentralized  Irrigation  Development  and  Management  Sector  Project  WUAs  (see 
Appendix  6,  Table  5.2);  and  (ii)  support  for  the  Decentralized  Irrigation  Development  and 
Management Sector Project WUAs. ADB’s statement of expenditure procedures shall be used 
to  reimburse  expenditures  and  liquidate  the  imprest  accounts  for  all  individual  payments  not 
exceeding the equivalent of $100,000. The grants will be disbursed by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook  and  detailed  arrangements  agreed  by  the  Government, 
ADB and IFAD.  The funds flow chart is in Supplementary Appendix G.

8. 

Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 

45. 
The  PCO  and  each  PPO  will  maintain  records  and  accounts  by  financing  source,  and 
identify expenditures incurred for the Project using grant proceeds and local financing sources. 
Accounts  will  be  established  and  maintained  in  accordance  with  internationally  accepted 
accounting  standards.  Annual  project  accounts  of  the  PCO  and  PPOs  will  be  audited  by 
auditors  acceptable  to  ADB.  Audit  coverage  will  include  a  special  audit  of  project  accounts, 
including separate opinions on (i) utilization of the imprest and project advance accounts; (ii) the 
statement of expenditures, including whether the amount claimed is duly supported and verified; 
(iii) whether the PCO and PPOs are operating the imprest and advance accounts in accordance 
with  ADB  procedures;  and  (iv)  compliance  with  financial  covenants  specified  in  the  grant  and 
project  agreements.  Audit  reports, management  letter,  and  related  financial  statements  will  be 
submitted to ADB not later than 6 months after the end of the fiscal year to which they relate, or 
the project closing date if earlier. ADB informed the Government of its policy on submission of 
audited  accounts  (covering  failure  of  submitting  audited  accounts  and  financial  statements  by 
the due date). Formal warning will be issued, and disbursements suspended, for accounts more 
than 6 months overdue. 
 
46. 
Each PPO will provide quarterly progress reports to the PCO. These will be consolidated 
into quarterly reports and submitted to MAF, the NPSC, ADB, IFAD, and PCCs. These reports 
will  record  progress  made,  problems  encountered  during  the  review  period,  steps  taken  or 
proposed  to  remedy  the  problems,  the  proposed  program  of  activities,  and  progress  expected 
for the following quarter. The PCO will ensure that these reports are submitted to ADB and IFAD 
in a timely manner. Within 6 months of physical completion of the Project, the PCO will submit 
to ADB and IFAD a project completion report that describes the physical progress of the Project, 
actual costs incurred in relation to cost estimates, the results of capacity building activities, the 
outcome of safeguard efforts, a preliminary assessment of achieved benefits, and other relevant 
project implementation matters requested by ADB. 
 

9. 

Project Performance Monitoring System 

47. 
The  PPMS  will  in  part  be  based  on  individual  subprojects  in  accordance  with  a  pre-
designed framework for implementation and impact monitoring.23 Baseline data (disaggregated 
by gender and ethnicity) will be obtained during subproject preparation, and presented as part of 
the  subproject  design  and  monitoring  framework.  A  set  of  qualitative  indicators  to  monitor 
capacity development for the Project as a whole will also be developed.24 Capacity building will 
be initially assessed through a baseline needs assessment, which will involve both an objective

10. 

Project Review 

48. 
Apart  from  regular  reviews,  ADB,  IFAD  and  the  Government  will  undertake  a 
comprehensive review within 12 months and annually following loan effectiveness when the first 
batch of subprojects has been identified and is under implementation. A midterm review will also 
be  undertaken  within  36  months  of  loan  effectiveness.  These  reviews  will  include  a 
comprehensive  assessment  of  project  implementation  arrangements,  detailed  analysis  of  the 
scope  and  implementation  process  and  progress  of  subprojects,  feedback  from  the  PPMS, 
performance  of  consultants,  capacity  building  progress,  and  possible  reallocation  of  loan 
proceeds. Remedial action will be instituted as required. 
 

IV. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

49. 
Given  the  current  high  levels  of  investment  in  the  agriculture  sector  (private  domestic, 
FDI,  and  donor-funded  initiatives),  the  proposed  Project  will  develop  national  and  provincial 
capacities to manage this recent surge of investment. It is proposed that capacity development 
TA financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan, 
will provide resources for international and national specialists to develop training material and 
provide  on-the-job  training  as  subprojects  are  screened,  prioritized,  and  evaluated.  Under  the 
TA, staff from line agencies will be trained to ensure that social and environmental safeguards 
compliance  is  incorporated  into  investment  proposals,  and  to  monitor  adherence  of  approved 
investments with specified covenants. Details of the proposed TA are in Appendix 9. 
 

V. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Institutional Impact 

50. 
The  overall  value  of  capacity  building  activities  to  the  economy  was  not  quantified,  but 
improved  national  and  provincial  capabilities  to  make  informed  decisions  about  investment  in 
the  sector  (public,  private,  and  from  FDI)  will  contribute  significantly  to  the  Government  being 
able to take control of the land allocation process on a more rigorous basis. This will enable it to 
protect the interests of smallholders whose livelihoods depend on the natural resources under 
their  area  of  control.  The  increase  in  technical  capacity  will  lead  to  considerable  efficiencies 
within the future land allocation process by clearly identifying areas suitable for different forms of 
agricultural  and  forestry  production,  and  demarcating  areas  set  aside  for  protection—while 
maximizing economic rents for the state from land concessions. 
 
B. 

Social Impact 

51. 
An  analysis  of  the  project  benefits  indicates  that  the  more  significant  social  impacts 
caused  by  the  subprojects  will  be  improved  livelihoods  and  reduced  levels  of  poverty  for  the 
population of the project area. Land suitability assessments and land use planning will enhance 
farmers’  awareness  of  suitability  for  various  crops  to  maximize  benefits,  and  facilitate  land 
allocation  and  titling—providing  security  of  tenure  and  associated  benefits.  The  provision  of 
improved  road  access  to  ethnic  minorities  and  farmers  living  in  isolated  and  inaccessible 
mountain areas is likely to have a positive impact, providing them with an outlet for their produce 
and  access  to  lower  priced  household  commodities,  agricultural  inputs,  as  well  as  health  and 
education  facilities.  The Project  is  classified category  A  for  indigenous peoples,  and  an  ethnic 
group  development  framework  agreed  in  accordance  with  the  Government’s  applicable  laws 
and  regulations  and  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous  Peoples  (1998).  The  framework  will  help 
extend  subproject  positive  impacts  to  ethnic  groups  and  mitigate  negative  impacts,  if  any.  A 
summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  is  in  Appendix  10.  A  summary  ethnic  group 

  

 

17

development framework is in Appendix 11 and a detailed ethnic group development framework 
is in Supplementary Appendix H. 
 
52. 
Improvement of rural access roads, irrigation facilities, and other rural infrastructure will 
be within existing road alignments as much as possible. It is envisaged that irrigation facilities 
and  other  items  of  infrastructure  will  be  rehabilitated  in  their  current  locations.  Priority  will  be 
given to those subprojects that can avoid or minimize resettlement impacts. If any exist, they are 
expected  to  be  insignificant  (category  B).  A  resettlement  framework  has  been  prepared 
(Appendix 12 and Supplementary  Appendix I) and sets out the resettlement policy, screening, 
and  planning  procedures  that  the  Project  will  follow  when  preparing  a  resettlement  plan  if 
required. 
 
Gender impacts will be facilitated through consultation with local women in the design of 
53. 
subprojects and by their inclusion in project activities (including extension services and training). 
Infrastructure  management  bodies  will  include  women.  Gender  training  will  be  provided  and 
linked to this concrete action in subproject preparation. Gender focal points may be established 
in  villages  to  promote  improved  agricultural  practices,  taking  account  of  women’s  traditional 
rights in land reallocation and land titling (Appendix 13 and Supplementary Appendix J). More 
generally,  improved  road  access  will  open  up  new  opportunities  for  women  who  lived  in 
previously  isolated,  rural  communities—giving  better  access  to  education  and  health  services, 
investment  opportunities  (Appendix  13  and 
as  well  as 
Supplementary Appendix J).

Environmental Impact 

The  Project’s  primary  focus  is  on  capacity  building  for  sustainable  ANR  management, 
54. 
which  entails  nonintrusive  initiatives  with  institutions.  The  developed  capacity  will  enhance 
environmental  benefits  and  promote  the  environmental  stability  of  subprojects.  In  examining 
land concessions, MAF and PAFOs will ensure that encroachment does not occur into protected 
areas and that any commercial ventures already allocated concessions in such areas will have 
their  lease  revised  accordingly.  Protection  forest  will  also  be  clearly  demarcated  on  land  use 
and suitability maps to be prepared under the proposed Project. Based on the likely investments 
envisaged,  the  Project  has  been  classified  environmental  category  B.  An  initial  environmental 
two  sample  subprojects  was  undertaken 
the 
examination  (IEE) 
(Supplementary  Appendix  K)  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002).  The  IEEs 
show that most of the potential impacts will be positive, that no significant adverse impacts are 
anticipated, and an environmental impact assessment is not required. However, to ensure that 
all potentially adverse impacts are mitigated, careful screening of subprojects will be carried out 
and  an  environmental  management  plan  specifying  mitigation  measures  and 
funding 
requirements will be a prerequisite for approval. In addition, an environmental assessment and 
review  framework  has  been  prepared  (Supplementary  Appendix  K)  to  guide  the  EA  in 
undertaking environmental assessments of subprojects to be selected during implementation. 
 
D. 

Economic Impact 

the  Project  and 

for 

Benefits  from  rural  road  rehabilitation  include  reduced  travel  costs  and  times.  Indirect 
55. 
benefits include the diversification of sources of income, higher levels of agricultural productivity, 
greater  diversification  of  market-oriented  agriculture  crops,  improved  access  to  health  and 
education  services,  and  reduced  costs  of  inputs  and  household  commodities—all  leading  to 
reduced  levels  of  poverty  among  communities  served  by  the  roads.  This  is  confirmed  by 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  estimates  of  23.5%  for  a  sample  rural  road  rehabilitation 
subproject,  based  on  quantifiable  benefits.  The  benefit  of  irrigation  rehabilitation  includes 
increased  agriculture  production  and  diversification  to  higher  value  crops.  The  sample 

 

 18 

 

 

subproject analyzed shows the intensification from a single rain-fed rice crop to two irrigated rice 
crops,  although  other  higher  valued  options  are  available  with  the  more  secure  dry  season 
water  supplies  leading  to  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  19.3%.  All  the  benefits 
anticipated are incremental in relation to the without-project scenario, where it may be expected 
that  the  incidence  of  land-use  conflicts  increase,  social  and  environmental  consequences 
intensify,  and  suboptimal  economic  returns  (to  the  state  and  public  lands  and  to  Lao  labor) 
worsen. Detailed economic analysis is in Appendix 14. 
 
E. 

Assumptions and Risks 

56. 
The design logic of the Project assumes that inflows of FDI into the Lao PDR continue, 
there is ongoing availability of appropriate improved agriculture technology upon which to base 
productivity improvements, processes of increasing regional integration and market participation 
underpin improving producer incentives, and the broad mix of government policies in the ANR 
sector remain consistent. 
 
57. 
The  main  institutional  risk  to  the  Project  lies  in  potential  conflict  between  certain 
provinces which have recently enjoyed considerable latitude in the award of land concessions 
and state agencies (such as NLMA) which are trying to standardize and rationalize the situation 
from  a  national  perspective.  This  risk  has  been  mitigated  by  involving  high-level  political 
authority  from  the  provinces  in  the  design  process.  A  second  risk  concerns  the  allocation  of 
funds  for  O&M  of  rural  infrastructure  rehabilitated  under  the  Project.  This  is  a  systemic  and 
ongoing  issue,  as  cash-limited  provincial  authorities  are  responsible  for  maintenance  of  state 
assets  but  receive  few  resources  from  the  national  budget  to  carry  out  routine  and  periodic 
maintenance. This will be mitigated by requiring provinces in which subprojects are located to 
sign formal commitments to provide financing to meet O&M expenses, and by the Government 
providing a specific assurance that it will allocate sufficient funds for the same purpose. 
 
58. 
A third risk is that capacity building initiatives are insufficient to achieve the competence 
needed for improved natural resource management, particularly in land suitability identification. 
This is mitigated by the continual input of technical specialists in the provinces throughout the 
first 3 years of implementation to provide the necessary support. The governance issue raised 
above will determine if the technical recommendations are seriously considered in making land 
allocation decisions. 
 
59. 
A  final  risk  is  that  trained  staff  will  leave  their  posts  after  receiving  training  under  the 
Project.  This  remains  a  constant  threat  in  economies  where  skilled  individuals  are  few  in 
number  and  opportunities  for  advancement  are  plenty.  The  broader  project  benefit  can  be 
served  as  long  as  the  trained  individual  continues  to  serve  economic  development  within  the 
Lao PDR and performance-based incentives are instituted.

A. 

Background 

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

The economy of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) is largely dependent 
1. 
on  an  undeveloped  and  low-productivity  agriculture  and  natural  resources  (ANR)  sector  to 
support  the  majority  of  its  population.  The  proportion  of  households  that  can  be  described  as 
agricultural remains high (at around 80%) and over 90% of these produce rice, mainly for their 
own  consumption.  Sector  growth  rates  averaged  almost  5%  in  the  5  years  to  2000,  but  have 
declined since to about 2%–3% per year. This growth came mainly from yield increases in rice, 
but  also  from  modest  moves  toward  higher  value  cropping  in  lowland  areas.  Agriculture  has 
remained a relatively extensive activity compared with other countries in the region, but national 
rice  yields  are  still  low  by  regional  standards.  Input  use  is  still  about  one-tenth  that  of  most 
countries in the region. National agricultural value added remains low, as is the openness of the 
sector (the lowest in the Greater Mekong Subregion). 
 
2. 
The  Lao  PDR  achieved  national  food  self-sufficiency  at  the  turn  of  the  century.  It  is 
widely agreed that aggregate annual production of rice, other grains and staples (roots, tubers, 
etc.) on average meet national calorific requirements. However, the entire population does not 
enjoy secure food supplies. Seasonal and local deficits, especially in upland and remote areas, 
still occur with some frequency. 
 
3. 
As  well  as  geographic  (mountainous  topography)  conditions  and  particular  subsector 
issues  (such  as  the  irrigated  area  as  a  proportion  of  total  cropped  area  being  low),  the  rural 
economy  remains  broadly  affected  by  specific  deficiencies  including  (i)  the  availability  of  rural 
finance,  (ii)  a  generally  underdeveloped  private  sector,  and  (iii)  the  poor  state  of  the  transport 
network (especially roads—both rural roads and links connecting the Lao PDR to other Greater 
Mekong  Subregion  countries).  Geographical  isolation  is  a major  cause  of  poverty,  as  much  of 
the rural population has limited access to markets, employment opportunities, or social services. 
 
4. 
Overall, the economy is primarily agrarian and natural resource-based, despite abundant 
natural  resources  and  an  apparently  favorable  policy  climate  that  has  facilitated  economic 
growth at the national level. ANR sector transition (i.e., agricultural intensification, diversification, 
and agro-industrialization) has not yet occurred, and the sector’s contribution to national poverty 
reduction has so far been modest. 
 
5. 
In response to the Sixth National Socio Economic Development Plan (2006–2010) and 
National  Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication  Strategy  objectives,  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and 
Forestry (MAF) has formulated four goals and 13 measures for the sector to guide development. 
However,  the  current  planning  system  does  not  embody  economic  prioritization  or  choice 
between alternatives (i.e., more robust policy making is required, especially at local levels). In 
addition,  whatever  objectives  may  exist  in  state  plans,  inadequate  operational  resources  and 
significant  control  over  expenditures  by  provincial  authorities  (because  of  their  tax-raising 
powers) can frustrate and/or undermine state objectives. The Asian Development  Bank (ADB) 
and  the  World  Bank  are  working  to  put  in  place  a  medium-term  expenditure  framework  at 
sectoral  and  national  levels.  It  is  questionable  whether  the  structure  of  MAF  operations 
(historically developed as an input and service provider across a range of activities) can meet 
the  needs  of  increasingly  export-oriented,  sophisticated,  and  service-demanding  production 
systems. 
 
6. 
Although  problems  in  governance  conditions  have  been  identified  and  described  for 
many years, the relatively poor sector governance is now an obvious constraint to the promotion 
of sustainable and equitable resource-based development. Agricultural growth has the potential 

 

 26 

Appendix 3 

to  benefit  the  majority  of  the  poor  directly.  However,  this  growth  (including  in  foreign  direct 
investment  [FDI])  depends  on  the—currently  absent—transparency  and  predictability  in  the 
implementation of investment laws, the enforcement of contracts, and management of the trade 
regime  and  taxation  procedures.  Similarly,  farmers,  agribusiness  enterprises,  and  investors 
must  have  confidence  in  relation  to  their  land  tenure  and  usufruct  rights  to  ensure  security  of 
their  property  and  investment.  Such  rights  are  largely  unenforceable  at  present.  Aggregate 
agricultural growth also depends on protecting national water, soil, and forest resources, e.g., by 
controlling the commercial and population-driven loss of forest, by managing the award of large-
scale land concession, and other significant resource alienation. However, government capacity 
to monitor and regulate and to impose penalties for illegal acts is extremely modest. Changes 
required  to  increase  the  long-term  sustainable  sector  growth  rate  will  depend  largely  on  the 
overall governance function, and how well domestic organizations and institutions perform. 
 
B. 

Recent Developments and Current Issues 

traders  and  processors);  and 

7. 
The  most  notable  feature  of  the  ANR  sector  is  the  unprecedented  pace  at  which  the 
sector  (and  thereby  the  country  itself)  is  being  integrated  with  neighboring  economies, 
particularly through flows of FDI. This inward investment is manifest in (i) cross-border contract 
farming  arrangements  (typically  between  Lao  smallholders  and  Thai,  Chinese,  or  Vietnamese 
purchasers, 
(ii)  plantation-style  commodity  production 
concessions.  Many  of  these  involve  Chinese  (for  rubber,  mainly  in  the  north),  Vietnamese 
(mainly rubber and coffee in the south), Korean (Jotropha for bio-diesel fuel), and Indian (pulp 
and paper based on fast-growing wood fiber) companies. Many of the Chinese and Vietnamese 
agencies  are  State  Owned  Enterprises,  often  exploiting  historical  political  and  patronage 
linkages  with  particular  provinces.  The  scale  of  these  developments  is  significant  (153,000 
hectares  have  been  allocated  in  Savannakhet  alone  and  total  national  land  concessions  may 
number  900  separate  agreements).  Concession  areas  in  the  southern  provinces  already 
represent 35% of the paddy area (Table A3).

8. 
Such concession investments have the potential to create large numbers of jobs for the 
local  population;  and  can  bring  skills,  technology,  intellectual  property,  etc.  to  the  Lao  PDR. 
However,  major  concerns  remain.  Land  is  given  to  applicants  for  long  lease  periods.  This  is 
often done under provincial authority, the status of which is unclear, and whose administrative 
and  financial  processes  are  opaque.  Lease  periods  of  20,  30,  or  50  years  are  common. 
Concessions  are  frequently  given  on  a  first-come,  first-served  basis  without  any  proper 
feasibility or safeguards-based analysis. There is little consideration as to the economic impact

ha.  

 

 Appendix 3 

27

on food security, local livelihoods, natural resources status, or the possibility that opportunities 
for  a  more  rewarding  investment  are  excluded  once  land  has  been  committed.  In  addition, 
annual  land  rentals  (typically  a  few  dollars  per  hectare)  are  extremely  low  in  light  of  the 
opportunity costs. 
 
9. 
The Government’s response to such arrangements is ambiguous. It involves confusion 
vis-à-vis legislation, and the mandates and authority of institutions; and outright conflict between 
the  state  and  certain  provinces.  The  public  sector  response  can  best  be  described  as 
administratively  and  technically  underdeveloped—it  simply  does  not  have  the  capacity  to 
appraise and monitor such arrangements. The limited capacity of ANR institutions in this regard 
is  the  core  sector  problem  and  desired  outcome  to  remedy  this  situation.  Without  the  Project, 
the  nature  of  many  such  investments  could  be  (i)  environmentally  damaging,  either  through 
relatively  short-term  exploitation  or  longer-term  neglect;  (ii)  non-transparent,  thus  benefiting 
foreign and nonpoor interests; and (iii) economically suboptimal, in terms of adding to domestic 
employment, income-generation, and wealth-creation. 
 
There  are  also  concerns  from  the  impact  of  major  international  price  changes  (rice  - 
10. 
doubling  between  early  2007  and  early  2008)  and  to  fuel-based  inputs  (inorganic  fertilizers, 
pesticides, herbicides, etc.). These changes have affected the dynamics of rice production and 
consumption  in  ways  that  remain  unclear,  as the  rice  economy  is  characterized  by  a  complex 
interplay of production and consumption factors. At the policy level, a proper understanding is 
required  of  (i)  the  extent  to  which  rice  production  should  be  promoted  (in  aggregate  and  at 
specific locations), and (ii) the opportunity costs of any particular level of national food security. 
Perhaps  even  more  urgently,  at  the  investment  level,  specific  interventions  are  needed  to 
increase the productivity of rice and other staples. This may be achieved through replication of 
successful irrigation  rehabilitation  schemes;  and  promotion  and  formation  of  farmer  groups  (to 
improve post-harvest handling, undertake marketing, devolve scheme management, etc.). 
 
11. 
Recent  FDI  and  land-based  investments  from  neighboring  countries  in  the  ANR  sector 
may be seen as a gold rush. However, as the economy becomes more formally integrated into 
worldwide  relationships  in  the  longer  term,  it  will  be  more  affected  by  global  (as  opposed  to 
merely  local  and  regional)  factors.  These  will  include  the  effects  of  engaging  new  and  higher 
value  products,  intensifying  and  extending  supply  chains,  more  rigorous  quality  standards, 
better information, etc. There is an urgent need to strengthen Lao PDR value chains, add value 
to  existing  products,  and  encourage  product  diversification  through  specific  investments  to 
address  and  exploit  such  possibilities.  At  a  policy  level,  another  need  is  to  improve  the  Lao 
PDR’s ability to engage in global (World Trade Organization) and regional (e.g., Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations [ASEAN], ASEAN Free Trade Area, and ANR trade based on proper 
sanitary and phyto-sanitary measures. 
 
12. 
Overall, securing the natural resource base is a necessary but insufficient condition for 
ANR  sector  development.  Complementary  investments  must  raise  sector  productivity  on  a 
sustainable and equitable basis. 
 
13. 
The  project  design  is  based  on  identified  sector  problems.  It  has  incorporated  lessons 
from previous interventions by taking a strategic approach, focusing on binding constraints, and 
maximizing  donor  coordination.  It  integrates  with  other  ADB  interventions,  e.g.,  in  public 
expenditure management and national and sector trade facilitation. A sector lending modality is 
required  because  it  is  necessary  to  (i)  address  sector  capacity  needs  centered  on  the  land 
issues;  and  (ii)  promote  increased  ANR  productivity  and  natural  resource  management  at  a 
range of specific locations, with a variety of sector objectives (poverty reduction, food security, 
trade  promotion,  etc.).  The  subproject  identification  and  selection  processes  will  ensure  that 
inclusive economic growth is fostered.
