SUMMARY SUBPROJECT IDENTIFICATION, PRIORITIZATION, AND APPROVAL 

 
A. 

Subproject Identification 

The format of proposals will be outlined as developed by the project coordination office 
1. 
(PCO).  Provincial  project  offices  (PPOs)  will  conduct  public  awareness  campaigns  to  elicit 
subproject proposals. These public awareness campaigns include meetings, workshops, radio, 
flyers,  and  other  types  of  media  to  reach  the  broader  rural  community.  They  will  disseminate 
information  such  as  a  general  description  of  potential  subprojects,  with  details  of  eligibility 
criteria  and  subproject  value  limits  ($100,000–$500,000),  and  a  subset  of  smaller  subprojects 
value  limits  ($20,000–$100,000)  and  criteria  to  be  used  in  prioritizing  proposals,  as  well  as 
application  and  processing  procedures.  PPOs  will  ensure  that  awareness  campaigns  are 
conducted  in  a  form,  manner,  and  language  that  enables  them  to  be  understood  by  ethnic 
groups,  women,  and  other  vulnerable  groups  within  rural  communities—particularly  in  priority 
poor districts and upland areas. 
 
B. 

Candidate Subproject Proposals 

2. 
The  first  step  will  be  to  identify  subproject  proposals  that  can  be  developed  into 
candidate subprojects by the district authorities. This will enable initial screening of proposals at 
the  district  level  so  that  certain  subproject  proposals  can  be  developed  further  into  feasibility 
studies.  Each  year,  the  provincial  vice  governor  will  issue  a  call  for  proposals  from  interested 
candidates  working  in  rural  development.  The  PCO  will  specify  a  format  in  which  subproject 
proposals should be submitted, and candidate proposals will need to be submitted to the district 
governor’s office in that format. This format would include at least (i) proponent contact details 
with summary credentials; (ii) an outline of scope and coverage of the subproject; (iii) an outline 
of summary costs; (iv) identification of main benefits and beneficiaries; and (v) an indication of 
whether  there  was  any  particular  social  (e.g.,  particularly  benefiting  disadvantaged  or  remote 
ethnic communities) or environmental issues associated with the subproject.  
 
3. 
Candidate  proposals  that  also  demonstrate  the  following  will  be  prioritized:  (i)  links  to 
ongoing  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  initiatives  or  proposals  (e.g.,  the  subproject 
produces  outputs  that  are  traded  across  borders,  access  the  East–West  Economic  Corridor, 
and benefit from GMS customs harmonization procedures; or involve technology transfer and/or 
skills  enhancement  from  a  neighboring  GMS  country);  or  (ii)  the  potential  for  positive  climate 
change  impacts  (ideally  being  eligible  for  support  under  schemes  such  as  the  Clean 
Development Mechanism or the Asian Development Bank [ADB] Climate Change Fund). There 
are 
to 
commercialization  of  agriculture,  (ii)  those  contributing  to  poverty  reduction,  and  (iii)  those 
contributing  primarily  to  resource  management.  To  ensure  that  the  Project  supports  balanced 
representation  among  these  categories,  a  ranking  mechanism  that  relies  on  weighting  various 
criteria to prioritize subprojects among these categories will be developed. This will be based on 
the  proposed  ranking  mechanism  below  (paras.  13–16),  to  allow  subproject  proposals  from 
each  category  to  compete  for  funding  approval.  Subproject  proposals  to  be  implemented  in 
priority  poor  districts  will  receive  additional  weighting  to  elevate  their  priority  in  the  selection 
process. 
 
4. 
Candidate  proposals  received  at  district  level  will  be  referred  to  PPOs.  Assisted  by 
technical  assistance  consultants  recruited  to  support  provincial  management  of  the  Project,

The  subproject  has  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  greater 
than 10%–12%. 
The subproject conforms to the recipient’s Sixth National Socio Economic 
Development Plan (2006–2010)1 and provincial agricultural development 
strategies acceptable to the recipient and ADB. 
The  subproject  will  be  an  agriculture  project  based  on  proven  technical 
parameters and implementation arrangements within the province or in a 
location  with  a  similar  agricultural  and  ecological  environment  for  the 
benefit of smallholders.  
The  subproject  will  be  identified  and  prioritized  based  on  the  needs 
assessment  and  any  updates  thereto,  and  will  be  further  selected  and 
designed  taking  beneficiary  and  affected  person  consultations  into 
account.  
The  subproject  reflects  the  requirement  for  a  reasonable  balance  of 
activities among communities and districts. 
The  subproject  will  have  a  significant  potential  impact  on  poverty 
reduction; and target poor districts, poor households, ethnic groups, and 
women. 
The subproject plans have been published in a form, manner, and place 
that  makes  them  available  to  affected  people;  public  comments  have 
been invited; and comments, including objections, have been published. 
The subproject must be technically feasible and represent the least-cost 
alternative,  taking  into  account  the  need  to  provide  for  a  reasonable 
increase in demand in the future.  
The  subproject  is  to  be  conducted  within  an  institutional  framework  that 
demonstrates  the  likelihood  that  it  will  be  financially  and  institutionally 
sustainable, including operation and maintenance (O&M) costs. 
The  equipment,  materials,  and  other  resources  can  be  acquired  in,  or 
transported  to,  the  subproject  location  without  unreasonable  obstruction 
or delay.  
The  subproject  can  be  completed  within  the  project  implementation 
period.  
The  subproject  is  in  compliance  with  the  laws  of  the  recipient,  including 
its environmental requirements, ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), ADB’s 
forest  policy, 2  and  the  environmental  requirements  set  forth  in  the 
environment  assessment  and 
(Supplementary

environmental clearance is obtained prior to the award of the subproject 
contract.  
The  subproject  will  involve  minimal  land  acquisition  or  involuntary 
resettlement.  If  either  of  these  is  required  for  a  subproject,  it  will  be 
conducted  in  conformity  with  ADB’s  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy 
(1995) and the resettlement framework (Supplementary Appendix I)

and  the  conditions  set  forth  in  the  ethnic  group  development  framework

5. 
Once  these  criteria  have  been  confirmed  by  PPOs,  subprojects  will  become  eligible  to 
receive  support  for  the  preparation  of  a  more  detailed  feasibility  study.  PPOs  will  report  the 
outcome  to  proponents,  with  a  copy  to  the  district  governor’s  office,  and  if  a  subproject  is 
rejected,  they  will  state  the  reasons  for  rejection,  to  provide  a  learning  process  and  enhance 
transparency.  Initial  screening  by  PPOs  should  be  completed  within  1  month  of  receipt  of 
proposals. 
 
6. 
A  full  feasibility  study  for  each  candidate  subproject  will  be  carried  out  under  the 
supervision of the PPO and by relevant line agencies, in close consultation with sponsors and 
proposers, assisted by project–funded technical assistance as required. The PCO will develop 
standard  requirements  for  the  detailed  feasibility  study  that  are  acceptable  to  ADB  and  will 
inform PPOs of these requirements. The PCO should also address all compulsory and scored 
criteria  outlined  below  (paras.13–16)  to  facilitate  comparison  between  projects  of  a  different 
category.  They  will  include  clear  identification  of  the  O&M  expenditures  necessary  to  sustain 
economic  benefits.  Completed  feasibility  studies  will  be  submitted  to  the  relevant  PPO  for 
prioritizing, using the prescribed criteria and ranking system. 
 
C. 

Eligible Subproject Proposals 

The prioritization of candidate subprojects into eligible subprojects for submission to the 

7. 
national level will be undertaken in accordance with the ranking mechanism below.  
 
8. 
All technical and financial estimates used in  the feasibility studies should be ratified by 
qualified personnel available within the province. Based on the adjusted weightings assigned to 
each  candidate  subproject  feasibility  study  (paras.13–16  below),  a  summary  report  will  be 
submitted  to  the  provincial  coordination  committee  for  consideration.  Those  recommended  by 
the provincial coordination committee shall be forwarded to the PCO while those rejected will be 
returned to the proponent with an explanation of the reasons behind the decision. 
 
The PCO shall refer the feasibility studies to a technical review committee to confirm the 
9. 
technical basis for the subprojects. The technical review committee will comprise experts from 
relevant ministries and departments, including but not limited to Agriculture and Forestry and its 
various departments, Water Resources and Environment Administration, Commerce and Trade, 
Communication,  Transport  Post  and  Construction,  etc.  Others  may  be  co-opted  from  the 
Government or private sector as required. After receiving technical confirmation, the PCO shall 
refer  eligible  subprojects  to  the  national  project  steering  committee  (NPSC)  for  approval  and 
funding commitment.  
 
10. 
Because  of  the  importance  of  adequately  maintaining  rural  infrastructure  to  sustain 
benefit  flows,  provinces  in  which  subprojects  are  to  be  located  will  be  required  to  sign 

 

 34 

Appendix 5 

commitments  that  they  are  prepared  to  meet  the  identified  O&M  expenditures  with  matching 
grants  from  the  Project  under  a  well-defined  institutional  and  financial  recovery  arrangement. 
Failure of provinces to sign such commitments or to provide the O&M  funds once subprojects 
are implemented will disqualify them from submitting future proposals.   
 
11. 
A works and service contract will then be developed by the PCO in cooperation with the 
relevant national agency, depending on the nature of the approved subproject. This contract will 
specify  the  time  frame,  financing,  benchmarks,  disbursement  schedule,  and  reporting 
requirements for each subproject. Failure by the contractor or service provider to adhere to the 
agreement will lead to suspension of financing. In the first 2 years, subprojects will be required 
to  obtain  no  objections  from  ADB  and  the  International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development 
(IFAD). 
 
D. 

Prioritization Mechanism 

12. 
Apart from the criteria used in the screening process, additional criteria will be used to 
facilitate the prioritization of subprojects given their different objectives and outcomes. A score- 
based system will be adopted for the three categories of subprojects: (i) rural poverty-focused 
subprojects, 
resource 
management-based  projects.  Different  weightings  will  be  applied  to  the  different  types  of 
subprojects to facilitate this prioritization process.  
 

rural  commercialization-based  subprojects,  and 

(iii)  natural 

(ii) 

1. 

Rural Poverty Reduction Subprojects 

For rural poverty reduction subprojects, the indicators shall have the following weights: 
13. 
(i)  A  =  the  EIRR  (10%);  (ii)  B  =  the  number  of  individuals  below  the  established  poverty  line 
assisted per $1,000 invested (40%); (iii) C = the equity contribution of beneficiaries (10%); and 
(iv)  D  =  the  district  is  considered  poor  (40%).  The  first  criterion  is  an  indication  of  economic 
viability,  the  second  an  indicator  of  project  impact  and  efficiency  of  impact  (particularly  on 
poverty  reduction),  the  third  is  an  indicator  of  ownership  by  subproject  proponents  or 
beneficiaries,  and  the  fourth  is  to  ensure  prioritization  of  proposals  from  priority  poor/upland 
districts.  
 
14. 
The highest data for each of the evaluation criteria from the subprojects being evaluated 
will be given a rating of 1.00 point. The scores for evaluation criteria of the other proposals will 
be computed accordingly as a ratio to the highest score. Proposals will be ranked according to 
their combined scores using the formula below: 
 

I = (0.10×A) + (0.40×B) + (0.10×C) + (0.40×D) 
 

2. 

Rural Commercialization Subprojects 

15. 
For  rural  commercialization  subprojects,  the  criteria  indicators  shall  have  the  following 
weights: (i) A = the EIRR (60%); (ii) B = the number of individuals below the established poverty 
line assisted per $1,000 invested, excluding labor in kind (15%); (iii) C = the equity contribution 
of  beneficiaries  (25%). Proposals  will  be  ranked  according  to  their  combined  scores  using  the 
following formula: 
 

I = (0.60×A) + (0.15×B) + (0.25×C) 

 

 

 Appendix 5 

35

3. 

Natural Resources Management Subprojects 

16. 
For  natural  resources  management  subprojects,  an  additional  indicator  is  needed  to 
quantify  the  degree  of  threat  to  the  resource.  This  will  be  calculated  on  a  score  of  1–5,  with 
1 being a low level of threat, and 5 being an extreme and immediate threat to the resource. The 
degree of threat will be confirmed by an environmental specialist during the feasibility study, and 
confirmed at later stages of assessment. An extreme and immediate threat would mean that the 
proposal  is  more  deserving  of  an  investment  to  mitigate  the  threat.  For  natural  resource 
management  subprojects,  the  criteria  indicators  shall  have  the  following  weights:  (i)  A  =  the 
EIRR (25%); (ii) B = the number of individuals below the established poverty line assisted per 
$1,000 invested (25%); (iii) C = the equity contribution of beneficiaries (25%); and (iv) D = the 
degree of threat (25%). Proposals will be ranked according to their combined scores using the 
following formula: 
 

I = (0.25×A) + (0.25×B) + (0.25×C) + (0.25×D) 

 
E. 

Provincial Grant Allocations 

17. 
The allocation of grant funds between provinces for the implementation of subprojects is 
proposed to be made through an initial equal allocation of $2 million to each of the provinces, 
and can be supplemented by a proportional allocation based on the number of poor households 
within the project area. This will ensure that the upland and resource poor provinces have the 
opportunity  to  receive  an  allocation  based  on  the  incidence  of  poverty.  This  constitutes  a 
de facto measure for poverty targeting, but also provides a fair means for allocation among the 
provinces with their diverse capital base. Allocation of grant funds among potential subprojects 
in  accordance  with  their  orientation  (poverty  reduction,  commercialization,  or  natural  resource 
management)  will  be  addressed  through  the  assignment  of  weightings  in  the  prioritization 
process  mentioned  above  (paras.  13–16).  Progress  will  be  evaluated  after  1  year,  and 
subsequent allocation will be made based on performance vis-à-vis predetermined indicators.

CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
 

Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

A. 
 
1. 
The anticipated outcome of the attached capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
is as follows: (i) increased awareness of the importance of social and environmental safeguards 
when  allocating  natural  resources  for  investment  proposals;  (ii)  subprojects  implemented  that 
incorporate  safeguards  to  improve  beneficiary  ownership  of  subprojects;  (iii)  a  comprehensive 
set  of  training  material  for  use  in  subsequent  agency  training  throughout  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic  Republic;  and  (iv)  a  database  comprising  all  the  relevant  geographic  information 
system  (GIS)  data,  maps  at  various  scales,  and  data  pertaining  to  safeguards  compliance 
available at the national, provincial, and district levels. 
 
B. 

Methodology and Key Activities 
 
Given  the  current  high  levels  of  investment  in  the  agriculture  sector  (private  domestic, 
2. 
foreign  direct  investment,  and  donor-funded  initiatives),  the  Project  will  develop  national  and 
provincial capacities to manage this recent surge of investment, ensuring that full benefits are 
achieved  and  detrimental  impacts  minimized.  There  is  increased  recognition  of  the  need  to 
incorporate  social  and  environmental  safeguards  and  other  social  and  gender  compliance 
measures when preparing and implementing rural development projects. While this has been a 
requirement  by  donors  for  some  time,  appreciation  of  the  benefits  from  their inclusion  has  not 
been  recognized  within  the  government  implementing  agencies.  Experience  from  recently 
completed projects demonstrates that staff in the line agencies (especially at the provincial level 
and  below)  do  not  appreciate  the  benefits  obtainable  from  compliance  (e.g.,  increasing 
ownership,  making  designs  more  appropriate,  and  making  investments  sustainable).  Current 
laws  and  decrees  devolve  responsibility  for  rural  development  to  local  administrations;  and 
assign  responsibilities  to  them  for  safeguards  in  respect  of  land  acquisition,  resettlement, 
environmental  impact  assessment,  and  mitigation  and  community  participation  in  decision 
making.  Similarly, 
the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will need to be addressed in the preparation of subprojects. 
 
3. 
The  TA  (proposed  to  be  financed  from  the  Japan  Special  Fund)  will  fund  international 
and  national  specialists  to  develop  training  material  and  provide  on-the-job  training  as 
subprojects are screened, prioritized, and evaluated. Under the TA, national and provincial staff 
will  be  trained  to  ensure  that  social  and  environmental  safeguards  compliance  is  incorporated 
into  investment  proposals,  and  to  monitor  adherence  of  approved  investments  with  specified 
covenants. In addition, the TA will provide resources for equipment, materials, and training for 
the  development  of  a  database  at  the  national  and  provincial  levels,  recording  information  on 
(i) social,  economic,  and  environmental  evaluations  of  feasibility  studies  for  investment 
proposals; and (ii) records for monitoring compliance with safeguards.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

Targeting Classification:     General intervention 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The  Sixth  National  Socio  Economic  Development  Plan  (2006–2010)  proposes  prioritized  investment  in  the 
47 poorest  districts  (12  of  which  are  in  the  project  area),  comprising  rural  infrastructure  to  improve  livelihoods  and 
access.a  The  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  has  used  this  plan  to  formulate  its  strategic  vision,  which 
comprises four goals and 13 measures to achieve these goals. The four goals are (i) increased food production and 
security;  (ii) increased  production  of  materials  for  agro-processing;  (iii)  stabilization  of  shifting  cultivation  (the  main 
strategy  of  poverty  reduction  in  the  47  poorest  districts  while  providing  for  environmental  protection);  and 
(iv) sustainable  forest  management.  As  the  Project  will  develop  sector  management  capacities  and  finance 
subprojects,  contributing  to  investment  in  resource  management  and  productivity  enhancement  management,  the 
design is supportive of sector objectives. 
 
The  country  strategy  and  program  2007–2011  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  aims  to  promote  pro-poor, 
sustainable growth led by the private sector, by improving policies and institutional capacity to support broad-based, 
private  sector-led  growth.b  It  proposes  to  support  the  building  of  a  legal  and  regulatory  framework  and  developing 
capacity  in  sectors  and  subsectors—specifically  identifying  agriculture  as  a  target.  The  strategy  supports  greater 
involvement of civil society and mass organizations in the delivery of agriculture and basic social services. Support 
will  be  provided  to  private  business  associations  to  improve  their  ability  to  network,  develop  business  skills,  and 
advocate  on  behalf  of  their  membership—expanding  livelihood  opportunities  for  rural  women  as  well  as  men  in 
commercial agriculture and small and medium-sized enterprise development. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis 
1. Key Issues 
A key poverty issue is the impact from foreign direct investment (FDI) that limits smallholder access to land and forest 
resources from which smallholders obtain their traditional subsistence existence. There is poor coordination between 
central and provincial/district levels in the application of policies for FDI. The Government has the right to determine 
and change land categories, allowing local authorities to reclassify village land from “productive” to “unproductive” to 
meet concessionaires’ demands. Procedures for awarding concessions are not clear and awards take place in an ad 
hoc fashion. This institutional weakness and poor governance is compounded by a lack of awareness of safeguard 
issues.  The  demand  for  land  by  plantation-style  FDI  has  been  directed  at  areas  previously  used  in  swidden 
production systems, where ethnic groups predominate and poverty is most apparent. Some 75% of poor households 
countrywide are made up of members of  ethnic groups living in remote and upland areas on marginally productive 
land. 
 
2.  Design Features 
To  address  these  issues,  the  Project  will  develop  the  capacities  of  the  provincial  agriculture  and  forestry  offices  to 
identify land suitability for a range of potential crops so that informed decisions can be made  when allocating land. 
The  capacity  building  will  extend  to  strengthening  agency  staff’s  understanding  of  environmental  and  social 
safeguards  to  protect  the  interests  of  traditional  users  of  the  resources  under  consideration.  The  Project  will  also 
provide  funding  for  demand-based  rural  infrastructure  and  other  successful  subprojects  to  increase  agricultural 
productivity  to  facilitate  smallholder  participation  in  commercialization  in  the  market  economy.  While  many  of  the 
subprojects  are  expected  to  be  small-scale  rural  infrastructure  investments,  subproject  design  will  incorporate  land 
tenure  activities  to  protect  the  interests  of  traditional  land-users  in  subproject  areas.  The  skills  developed  in  land 
suitability  mapping  using  geographic  information  systems  can  readily  be  applied  to  subproject  design  to  demark 
protected  and  production  forest  areas  to  be  managed  by  villagers.  These  subprojects  will  be  selected  through  a 
screening  process,  using  established  criteria  and  safeguards  outlined  in  Supplementary  Appendix  C,  which  ensure 
identification  of  appropriate  beneficiaries  with  attention  to  gender  issues  and  indigenous  people’s  concerns.  The 
Project  will  train  implementing  staff  in  developing  and  applying  mechanisms  for  the  participation  of  all  vulnerable 
groups, women, and ethnic minorities; and ensuring community demand is articulated.

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
In the year 2000–01, 304,100 households were classified “poor” throughout the country. This decreased to 166,600 
by  2005.  The  population  of  the  five  target  provinces  is  1.8  million,  ranging  from  0.8  million  in  Savannakhet  to 
0.11 million  in  Sekong.  While  the  poor  represent  38%  of  the  project  area’s  population,  the  incidence  of  poverty  in 
participating provinces varies from 42% in Savannakhet to only 5% in Sekong and 7% in Attapeu. The provinces with 
the greatest number and highest percentage of poor are Savannakhet and Champassak. At the village and  district 
level,  other  factors  are  brought  into  consideration  in  assessing  poverty,  including  access  to  education,  health 
services, road access, as well as access to clean drinking water. These criteria significantly alter the perspective of 
poverty from the income-based assessment with individual households. 
 
There  are  40  districts  in  the  five  provinces,  of  which  19  are  considered  priority  poor  (7  in  Savannakhet,  4  in 
Champassak, 3 in Salavan and Attapeu each, and 2 in Sekong). Within these poor districts, household poverty levels 
average over 50% although Champassak has a figure closer to 20%. Assessed on a village basis, about 70% of the 
villages are poor; this ranges from 50% in Champassak to over 80% in Attapeu and Sekong. Proportional figures are 
misleading,  though,  and  the  actual  numbers  of  poor  households  are  by  far  the  greatest  in  Savannakhet  and 
Champassak, accounting for over 70% of the poor households in the participating provinces. A further dimension of 
poverty  relates  to  the  predominance  of  ethnic  groups  within  the  target  area.  About  half  of  the  population  in  the 
five provinces  is  comprised  of  indigenous  peoples  known  in  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  as 
ethnic  groups,  mostly  from  the  Mon-Khmer  language  family.  The  proportion  of  ethnic  groups  is  highest  in  Sekong 
(88%) and Attapeu (63%) but actual numbers are greatest in Savannakhet and Champassak. Poverty is significantly 
higher among minority groups than in lowland Lao communities. 
 
Because  of  this  isolation,  villagers  are  heavily  dependent  on  forest  access  for  daily  edibles  and  non-timber  forest 
products, some of which are sold to earn cash for food purchase. In the five provinces, there are serious economic 
consequences  for  poor  villagers  that  lose  access  to  forest  resources  through  unrestrained  concession  award  and 
unplanned  relocation.  Some  concessionaires  are  clearing  and  converting  forestland  contrary  to  government  policy. 
FDI has increased the risk of staple food shortages. Ethnic minority villages are required to cease shifting cultivation 
and resettle at lower elevations, forming larger communities where government services can be provided.c  
 
Another  difficulty  with  merged  administrations  from  resettlement  is  that  several  different  ethnic  groups  are  often 
grouped together in one village or location, requiring longer preparation time for consultation with each set of elders. 
Those villages that have been resettled within walking distance of their old land continue to grow upland rice in these 
locations. However, because of the distance to these fields, they are not able to clear, plant, and maintain as large an 
area  as  before.  In  addition,  some  villagers  complain  of  declining  production  caused  by  a  combination  of  increased 
population  (as  a  result  of  merging  of  villages)  and  land  degradation.  Government  policy  on  reducing  shifting 
cultivation may also have limited village access to sufficient productive land. 
 
 
B. 
1. During the implementation of the TA, workshops and a number of meetings in provincial, district offices and 
villages were organized to seek views of stakeholders. During fact-finding mission (August 2008) a number of 
provincial and district government officials were consulted together with villages that had experience with FDI.

3. Was a consultation and participation (C&P) plan prepared?   
 
A C&P plan has been prepared and this is mainstreamed into the gender, disadvantaged persons and ethnic group 
action  plan.  Subproject  identification  is  based  on  community  demand.  Mechanisms  have  been  designed  to  ensure 
community participation and consultation in subproject survey, design and implementation. Government officers will 
be  trained  in  subproject  preparation  and  implementation  that  require  high  local  participation.  The  C&P  recognizes 
that ethnic groups and subgroups in communities require specific measures in order that their development priorities 
are  articulated.  Government  staff  will  receive  training  in  C&P  and  participatory  methods  including  gender  and 
disadvantaged  group  strategies.  The  Project  will  engage  local  community  assistance  in  the  implementation  of 
subprojects particularly in ethnic group communities utilizing skilled local people as community organizers assisting 
project staff.

C. Gender and Development 
 
1. Key Issues 
Rural  Lao  women  are  primarily  responsible  for  maintaining  family  food  security,  a  role  often  underestimated. 
Prevailing cultural values tend to disadvantage women in terms of their participation in politics and decision-making 
processes,  and  they  are  underrepresented  in  village  committees.  Similarly,  ethnic  group  women  are  not  well 
presented  in  government,  particularly  extension  workers,  health  care  workers,  and  teachers.  By  virtue  of  their 
geographic  location,  they  are  isolated  from  resources  and  services.  They  are  also  the  least  able  to  participate  in 
decision  making,  partly  because  of  illiteracy  and  cultural  traditions.  Linguistic  barriers  and  cultural  attitudes  toward 
education  perpetuate  low  human  development  and  the  vicious  cycle  of  poverty  in  which  many  ethnic  groups  find 
themselves. 
 
The  Government  has  asked  all  ministries  to  develop  strategies  and  action  plans  to  promote  gender  equality  at 
national, provincial, district, and village levels. Line agencies have begun to mainstream gender concerns. However, 
MAF has not started integrating gender into its planning cycle; its main efforts are in donor-funded projects. MAF has 
a  gender  focal  point  and  women  advancement  committee  but  its  role  and  responsibilities  are  not  clear—nor  is  it 
strong  enough  to  integrate  gender  policies  into  practice.  Constraints  on  gender  mainstreaming  in  MAF  are  a  poor 
understanding of gender concept and strategies, lack of resource persons with gender professional knowledge, and 
no statistical information related to gender issues. 
 
Land rights of women show a difference in the names and or titles that appear on the land documents and the origin 
of  the  land.  Only  16%  of  land  was  registered  in  the  wife’s  name,  although  40%  of  the  land  came  from  the  wife’s 
parents. Fifty-eight percent of land was registered in the husband’s name, although only 18% of the land came from 
the husband’s parents. Part of this situation can be attributed to the lack of knowledge on and difficulty in accessing 
information on women’s land rights. In addition, except for selected Mon-Khmer groups such as Brao, it is a generally 
held view that men are the head of household, so their names appear on administrative documents.

About half the population in the proposed target of five provinces (Attapeu, Champassak 
Saravane, Savannakhet, and Sekong) comprises non-Lao Loum ethnic groups.1 The five project 
provinces officially recorded 33 distinct ethnic minorities, not including small numbers of migrated 
groups from other provinces such as Lolo, Akha and Hor. Identified ethnic groups in the provinces 
belong to seven different Austro-Asiatic language groups and subgroups, including 13 Bahnaric 
(6 Bahnaric, 6 Bahnaric West, 1 Bahnaric North); 2 Palaungic; 9 Katuic; and 1 Vietic.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK 

 
1. 
Project  Background.  The  Sustainable  Natural  Resources  Management  and 
Productivity  Enhancement  Project  (the  Project)  comprises  (i)  capacity  building  of  central  and 
provincial  agencies  in  natural  resource  management  techniques  and  procedures;  (ii)  the 
implementation  of  a  number  of  subprojects  of  value  from  $100,000  and  $500,000  to  facilitate 
rural  development  within  the  target  provinces  of  Attapeu,  Champassak  Saravane,  Savannakhet, 
and  Sekong;  and  (iii)  project  management  and  implementation  support.  The  subprojects  to  be 
included  in  the  Project  will  be  selected  during  implementation  on  the  basis  of  agreed  criteria, 
including  the  number  of  people  expected  to  benefit,  poverty  level  of  beneficiaries,  minimal 
amount  of 
impact,  and  environmental  sustainability. 
Implementation of the subprojects will enable rural communities in the project area to maximize 
their  benefits  from  the  proposed  intervention.  Eligible  subprojects  involving  rural  infrastructure 
projects  will  include  rehabilitation  of  rural  roads,  access  tracks,  and  the  construction  and/or 
rehabilitation  of  small-  and  medium-scale  irrigation.  Other  eligible  subprojects  might  include 
initiatives  that  are  not  related  to  infrastructure,  such  as  the  extension  of  technical  support 
services to common interest farmer groups, or improving the linkages between producer groups 
and processors. Detailed design of subprojects, regardless of their nature, will explore all viable 
options to reduce the requirements for land acquisition and resettlement to the extent feasible. 

resettlement  and  environmental 

Preparation  of  Resettlement  Plans.  Improvement  of  rural  access  roads,  irrigation 
2. 
facilities, and other rural infrastructure will be within existing road alignments, irrigation facilities, 
etc. as much as possible. In addition, priority will be given to avoiding or minimizing resettlement 
impacts.  Therefore,  the  need  for  resettlement  plans  will  be  relatively  small.  Resettlement 
impacts, if any, are expected not to be significant (category B), so short resettlement plans will 
be prepared. 

3. 
Legal and Policy Framework. The resettlement framework is developed from the laws 
and  decrees  of  the  Government  of  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  and  the 
relevant  policies  and  guidelines  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  Provisions  and 
principles  adopted  in  the  resettlement  framework  will  supplement  the  provisions  of  relevant 
decrees currently in force in the Lao PDR wherever a gap exists. 

Objectives  and  Entitlements.  The  overall  policy  objective  is  to  ensure  that  all  people 
4. 
affected  by  the  Project  will  be  able  to  restore  their  pre-project  conditions,  while  the  poor  and 
vulnerable households will be able to improve their pre-project living standards. Compensation 
will be based on the principle of replacement cost while additional assistance in cash and kind 
will also be provided, depending on the severity of impacts. Relocation and income restoration 
measures for severely affected and vulnerable households will be designed and implemented in 
consultation with affected persons during resettlement plan preparation. Voluntary donation will 
not  be  applied  for  any  assets,  except  very  minor  losses  of  residential  land.  The  Project  will 
identify  any  specific  needs  or  concerns  to  be  considered  for  indigenous  peoples  groups  and 
other  vulnerable  groups  such  as  the  landless,  poor,  and  households  headed  by  women, 
disabled,  elderly,  or  children  without  means  of  support.  A  gender  strategy  and  ethnic  group 
specific actions, as required, will be included in the subproject resettlement plan. 
 
5. 
Consultation  and  Disclosure.  Consultation  will  be  undertaken  prior  to  finalization  of 
detailed  design  so  that  affected  persons’  requests  and  suggestions  to  minimize  resettlement 
impacts  can  be  incorporated  into  the  design  as  far  as  is  practicable.  Consultation  and 
participation activities will continue throughout project implementation to ensure that information 
about  the  overall  Project  and  resettlement-related  information  is  properly  understood  and 
accepted by the affected persons. 

 

 Appendix 12 

53

 
6. 
Implementation Arrangements. The Project will be managed by a project coordination 
office (PCO) to be established within the Department of Planning of the Ministry of Agriculture 
and Forestry (MAF). The PCO will be responsible for day-to-day management of the Project. At 
the provincial level, the Provincial Governors’ Office with its provincial project offices (PPOs) will 
be  responsible  for  overall  coordination  of  organizations  involved  in  resettlement  and  for 
resettlement plan preparation and updating, supervision, and management of resettlement plan 
implementation. A resettlement committee will be established in each province to prepare and 
implement resettlement plans, and will be supported by safeguards consultants. In accordance 
with  Decree  192/PM,  the  Water  Resources  and  Environment  Administration  (WREA)  and  its 
respective provincial representative offices will review and approve the resettlement plan prior to 
submission  to  ADB.  WREA  is  also  responsible  for  monitoring  of  resettlement  activities.  It  will 
review all internal and external monitoring reports and undertake periodic inspections. 

7. 
Grievance  Redress. At the central level, within MAF’s Department of Planning, a task 
force will be established to receive and resolve complaints and grievances or act upon reports 
from  stakeholders  on  projects  in  general,  including  grievances  caused  by  resettlement  and 
environmental issues. At the project level, the grievance procedure uses a five-step approach, 
i.e., affected persons can lodge their complaint with the village officials first and the case will be 
forwarded to the district, provincial and central level if the case is unresolved or not satisfactory 
to the affected persons. The last resort will be lodged with the Court of Law, whose decision will 
be  final.  Affected  persons  will  be  made  fully  aware  of  the  grievance  process  and  their  rights 
verbally and in writing during consultation, survey, and time of compensation. 
 
8. 
Monitoring and Budget. Primary responsibility for internal monitoring will lie with PPOs 
as  implementing  agencies  responsible  for  overseeing  the  formation,  function,  and  activities  of 
each  of  the  implementing  agencies  for  subprojects;  and  through  quarterly  monitoring  reports. 
The Ministry of Finance will be responsible for the disbursement of funds to each of the relevant 
Provincial Governor’s Offices. These funds will be managed by the resettlement committee. The 
Government  will  ensure  timely  provision  of  counterpart  funds  for  resettlement  to  meet  any 
unforeseen  obligations  in  excess  of  the  resettlement  budget  estimates  to  satisfy  resettlement 
requirements  and  objectives.  ADB  and  International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development  grant 
funds will be utilized for compensation for non-land assets, provision of necessary allowances, 
special  assistance  to  be  provided  to  vulnerable  affected  persons,  development  of  individual 
replacement  plots,  administration  costs,  and  external  monitoring.  The  resettlement  plans  will 
identify  key  activities  for  which  funds  will  be  used,  any  disbursal  milestones,  and  auditing 
requirements that will facilitate appropriate and timely delivery. 
 
9. 
Implementation  Schedule. Land acquisition, compensation, and relocation of affected 
persons cannot commence until the resettlement plan, when required for individual subprojects, 
has been reviewed and approved by ADB. Civil works may commence in sections where there 
are  no  resettlement  impacts.  All  resettlement  activities  will  be  coordinated  with  the  civil  works 
schedule.  The  PPO  will  not  allow  construction  activities  in  specific  sites  until  all  resettlement 
activities  have  been  satisfactorily  completed,  agreed  rehabilitation  assistance  is  in  place,  and 
the site is free of all encumbrances. 

10. 
Disclosure  of  Resettlement  Planning  Documents.  This  resettlement  framework  will 
be uploaded on the ADB website before appraisal. The PPO and resettlement committees will 
be responsible for disclosure of the resettlement plan to affected persons prior to submission to 
ADB. ADB will upload the final resettlement plan on ADB’s resettlement webpage.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 

Introduction 

A. 
 
In view of the sector lending modality, an economic analysis has been carried out on the 
1. 
proposed  loan  based  on  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  guidelines  contained  in  Economics 
Research Division Technical Note No. 14: Economic Analysis of a Sector Loan.1 The proposed 
Project  is  an  investment  grant.  However,  because  of  the  significant  number  and  location  of 
potential  subprojects  within  the  target  provinces,  it  was  not  possible  to  identify  all  subprojects 
during design—nor was it appropriate, as the Government  has already demonstrated capacity 
to implement a sector modality project. The Project also seeks to influence policy development 
and thereby qualifies as a sector loan. More detailed analysis of two representative subprojects 
(to  confirm  they  are  economically  viable  and  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction)  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix L. Further material on the sector (including its planning context) is in 
Appendix 3. 
 
B. 

Rationale for Government and ADB Involvement

incidence  of  conflict  over 

2. 
The  Government  is  ultimately  responsible  for  management  of  the  country’s  natural 
resources  to  ensure  their  current  and  continuing  productivity.  With  the  recent  and  largely 
unmanaged  surge  in  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI),  negative  impacts  are  already  becoming 
obvious.  The 
increased  dramatically,  with  both 
concessionaires and traditional landowners uncertain of their rights. FDI has effectively denied 
access  by  traditional  users  of  forest  areas,  and  their  livelihoods  have  been  threatened.  The 
short-term response was to introduce a moratorium on the issue of new land concessions until 
May  2008.  A  longer-term  solution  is  needed  to  rationalize  this  potentially  valuable  source  of 
investment, and manage it to minimize negative externalities. 
 
Another  part  of  the  rationale  for  government  involvement  is  that  rural  infrastructure  is 
3. 
largely a public good (benefits are largely non-excludable and non-subtractable).2 Infrastructure 
investments  tend  to  require  large  capital  resources,  which  preclude  private  investment,  since 
the  means  for  recovering  rents  or  user  charges  are  not  well  developed  in  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR),  in  spite  of  some  unachieved  policies  regarding  irrigation 
management and transfer.3 With the exception of irrigation facilities and water supplies, where 
target  beneficiaries  can  be  clearly  identified,  benefits  from  investment  are  distributed  over  a 
large  and  unidentifiable  number  of  users.  This  reinforces  the  public  nature  of  the  investment. 
Similarly,  the  proposed  support  to  producer  associations  and  farmer  groups  is  not  likely  to  be 
carried out by the private sector. 
 
4.  
ADB’s  comparative  advantage  as  a  participant  in  the  Project  arises  from  three  main 
sources.  Firstly,  previous  long-term  agriculture  and  natural  resources  and  multi-sector 
experience  (both  policy  and  project-based)  is  unmatched  by  any  other  donor  in  the  Lao  PDR. 
This  has  contributed  to  robust  project  design  and  will  continue  to  underlie  and  inform  project 
implementation, especially as a mixture of policy and technical support is envisaged. A history 
of  long-term  cooperation  with  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  (particularly  the 
Department of Planning) will provide a solid foundation for long-term implementation.

57

Secondly, ADB value added in the proposed investment is enhanced by its ability to both 
5.  
leverage International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) funding and integrate with the 
ongoing  work  of  other  donors.  The  World  Bank,  Agence  Francaise  Developpement,  and 
European Community are investigating major funding for initiatives in the north of the Lao PDR. 
Therefore, it makes sense in terms of donor harmonization for more attention to be paid—in the 
form  of  a  number  of  subproject  investments—to  the  relatively  neglected  southern  provinces 
(several of which are particularly remote in geographic and administrative/historical terms). 
 
Thirdly,  the  Project’s  location  and  its  constituent  activities  exploit  linkages  with  existing 
6.  
ADB-supported subregional initiatives. Insofar as they relate to the proposed Project, the three 
main  subregional  features  are  (i)  the  East–West  Economic  Corridor,  which  runs  across 
Savannakhet  and  whose  facilities  subprojects  will  be  able  to  exploit;  (ii)  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion  (GMS)  Core  Agriculture  Support  Program,  several  of  whose  key  strategic  thrusts 
directly support objectives and activities of the proposed Project (e.g., facilitation of cross-border 
trade  and  investment  in  agriculture,  policy  support  for  cross-border  contract  farming);  and 
(iii) the  GMS  Core  Environment  Program  and  Biodiversity  Conservation  Corridors  Initiative, 4 
where both skills and experiences of GMS countries will be solicited in project implementation 
(e.g., for land use planning and geographic information system training). 
 
C. 

Goals of the Plan 

7. 
The Government’s guiding document is the Sixth National Socio Economic Development 
Plan (2006–2010).5 MAF has translated its content into specific targets and objectives through 
its  own  strategic  document,  which  outlines  four  overall  objectives  to  be  achieved  through  the 
implementation of 13 measures. The four strategic objectives are (i) increased food production 
and security—annual food production equivalent of 3.3 million tons of rice, increasing national 
average consumption to 350 kilograms per head per year (including poor districts), together with 
other targets for protein; (ii) increased production of materials for agro-processing—directed at 
domestic processing to allow agriculture and forestry exports to increase to 30% of the value of 
exports ($1 billion by 2010); (iii) stabilization of shifting cultivation—the main strategy of poverty 
reduction  in  the  47  poorest  districts  while  providing  for  environmental  protection;  and  (iv) 
sustainable forest management—to increase forest cover from 42% to 53% (12 million hectares 
by 2010) with commercial plantations. The 13 measures have been developed to give effect to 
these  overall  objectives with  the  use  of  government  budget  and  donor  support,  and  are  being 
funded in part by donor and budget funds. One of the main items identified in the 13 measures 
is the need to improve market access through rehabilitation of rural infrastructure. 
 
D. 

Associated Economic Policies 

9. 
Two recent policy initiatives likely to affect the agriculture and natural resources sector, 
other  than  the  sector  development  policy  itself,  are  (i)  the  policy  on  decentralization—for  the 
management of land resources and technical support services, and (ii) the policy for maintaining 
irrigation infrastructure. As for the first, the Government has attached significant importance to 
the ability of kumbans (village clusters) and districts to identify investments. However, to date, 
the  funds  for  such  investments  are  essentially  limited  to  initiatives  funded  by  bilateral  and 
multilateral sources. Items identified at this level tend to be smaller-scale public investments of 
immediate  relevance  to  the  concerned  communities.  They  tend  not  to  have  the  broader

Initiative in the Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila (TA 6289-REG).

Appendix 14 

economic  development  rationale  or  any  appreciation  of  the  larger-scale  development  issues, 
such  as  connectivity  with  the  broader  intra-regional  road  network.  This  has  created  an 
opportunity  for  coordination  with  these  smaller  scale  investments  to  increase  their  impact. 
Linking  a  number  of  village  or  kumban  roads  with  a  district  road  has  the  potential  for  a  far 
greater impact than the road alignment in its own right. 
 
10. 
The  second  policy  is  related  to  irrigation  management  and  transfer.  The  Government 
wishes  to  recover  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  from  the  immediate  beneficiaries. 
Water users associations have been charged with responsibility for setting water service fees to 
recover  O&M  costs.  For  the  larger  schemes,  the  pricing  policy  does  not  provide  for  full  cost 
recovery.  In  many  cases,  recovered  user  charges  are  insufficient  to  meet  immediate  O&M 
needs and a significant public need remains to maintain the operations of pumping equipment 
that rely on expensive electricity. Local authorities cannot afford to finance comprehensive O&M 
as  provincial  budgetary  allocations  are  limited  and  assets  inevitably  deteriorate.  With  limited 
resources  available  in  districts  and  provinces  to  maintain  O&M  support  of  irrigation  facilities, 
particularly for more expensive periodic maintenance, facilities are seldom maintained in sound 
working order. The Project has addressed this issue by supporting further development of O&M 
policy by providing technical and policy specialists under the Project. 
 
E. 

Government and Local Consultant Capacity 

11. 
The Government has demonstrated capacity to implement ADB-funded sector modality 
projects  such  as  the  Community  Managed  Irrigation  Sector  Project,  the  Northern  Community 
Managed  Sector  Project,  and  the  Decentralized  Irrigation  Sector  Management  Project,  two  of 
which  are  due  to  be  completed  in  2009. 6  The  Government  has  demonstrated  capacity  to 
identify, prioritize, and prepare detailed designs for the implementation of these sector modality 
projects.  The  ADB-funded  Decentralized  Irrigation  Sector  Management  Project  is  being 
implemented through provincial project management units, where there was significant capacity 
building  in  the  identification,  design,  works  supervision,  and  project  management  in  general. 
While a recent review mission assessed that more capacity building was needed in safeguards 
and  economic  evaluation,  the  project  has  demonstrated  that  capacity  to  implement  the 
proposed Project has been established.  
 
F. 

Fiscal Impacts 

12. 
The majority of the subprojects will comprise a mix of rural infrastructure, together with 
“soft”  initiatives  for  farmer  group  support  or  technical  extension  services.  Most  of  the  rural 
infrastructure  rehabilitated  under  the  Project  will  be  of  sufficient  size  that  it  is  unlikely  that 
communities  will  assume  responsibility  for  its  maintenance.  In  the  case  of  irrigation 
rehabilitation, the Government is committed to charging water user charges to provide for O&M 
requirements. Where it is possible to identify and charge local beneficiaries for contributions to 
O&M, the immediate beneficiaries will be able to contribute to routine maintenance. For roads 
and other public infrastructure, the funding of periodic and routine maintenance will become the 
responsibility  of  the  provinces.  This  places  a  significant  demand  on  provincial  and  district 
resources.  While  the  revenue-raising  capacity  of  rural-based  provinces  is  limited,  the  issue  of 
is  very  much  dependent  on  central  government  budgetary  allocations. 
sustainability

59

Sustainability  is  only  partly  a  financial  management  issue;  it  is  more  an  issue  of  limited 
resources. 
 
13. 
A review of the financial positions of the five target provinces shows significant growth in 
the  level  of  financial  activity,  sources  of  funding,  and  allocation  of  these  funds  to  both  capital 
and  recurrent  expenditure.  In  the  12  months  ended  September  2007,  annual  budget  receipts 
per capita (from all sources) in the target provinces varied considerably. The highest was almost 
exclusively comprised of transfers from the central Government. Provinces maintain their focus 
on funding capital investment, accounting for about 20% of provincial expenditure on average. 
The heavy dependence on the central government for budget resources averages over 80% for 
target  provinces.  It  is  lower  in  Champassak,  where  there  is  a  rapidly  developing  trading 
economy  with  neighboring  countries.  In  Attapeu,  economic  development  opportunities  are 
limited and there is greater dependence on the central Government. The provincial allocation of 
maintenance budgets continues to be a challenge for resource-poor provinces. Furthermore, as 
their  economies  develop,  greater  allocations  will  be  needed  for  recurrent  expenditure  on 
maintenance rather than keeping their focus on new infrastructure investment. 
 
14. 
ADB  funds  are  not  fully  fungible  as  the  two  financing  sources—ADB  and  IFAD—have 
been specified in the design for subprojects. The allocation of counterpart funds has not been 
proposed in view of the limitations described. 
 
G. 

Economic Risks 

15. 
The  major  economic  risk  to  the  successful  outcome  of  the  Project  is  the  need  for 
periodic and routine maintenance to sustain benefits. The economic analysis in Supplementary 
Appendix L draws attention to the sensitivity of the economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) for 
the  representative  subprojects  to  maintenance  for  road  subprojects  in  particular.  If  the  benefit 
stream stops 5 years after rehabilitation, the estimated EIRR becomes negative; if this happens 
after  10  years,  the  EIRR  falls  below  the  cost  of  capital.  Sensitivity  analysis  of  the  Kaenghet 
Road  Rehabilitation  Subproject  suggests  that  the  EIRR  will  be  about  13.3%  if  maintenance 
stops after 5 years, and 20.7% if maintenance stops after 10 years. The situation is similar for 
the  Hatxaysoung  Irrigation  Rehabilitation  Subproject,  with  an  EIRR  of  14.6%  if  maintenance 
stops after 5 years and an EIRR of 18.5% if it ceases after 10 years. 
 
16. 
The  importance  of  attending  to  maintenance  of  rehabilitated  rural  infrastructure  cannot 
be  overstated,  as  it  has  such  a  dramatic  impact  on  the  benefits  achieved.  The  economic  risk 
identified is partly related to policy—tariffs do not reflect the real operational cost of rehabilitated 
infrastructure—but  is  equally  a  function  of  limited  resources  to  maintain  structures.  The 
subproject  identification  process  will  partly  ensure  that  resources  are  allocated  to  the 
rehabilitated  infrastructure,  but  there  will  be  a  period  of  time  between  the  commitment  to  a 
maintenance  program  and  the  commitment  of  budgetary  resources  during  which  such 
undertakings  could  be  forgotten.  It  is  therefore  important  to  formalize  commitments  for 
maintenance  by  the  provinces  and  set  minimum  financing  quantities  for  specific  items  of 
infrastructure where possible. 
 
H. 

Government Commitment 

17. 
The commitment of both central and provincial government was strong during the ADB-
funded preparation of the Project.7 This was manifest, among other things, by the presence of

considerable  merit  in  the  scope  and  objectives  of  the  Project,  as  it  has  been  developed  in  a

is  clear,  as  it  has  welcomed  the  overall  objectives  and  it  will  build  local  capacities  where  the

the past. 
 
I. 

individual  consultations.  What 

Coordination of Foreign Aid 

There  are  a  number  of  international  agencies  and  bilateral  donors  working  in  rural 
18. 
development  (Appendix  4)  as  well  as  limited  state-funded  initiatives.  The  Government  has 
promoted  a  broad-based,  sector-wide  approach  to  coordinate  rural  development  for  improving 
the impact from donor support, improving communication between donors, and adopting a more 
unified approach under the Government’s guidance. The formation of the upland working group 
in the north of the country appears to be an effective means for coordinating donor support. The 
ADB and IFAD-funded project has worked closely with this group during project preparation, as 
a  number  of  policy-related  topics  are  common  to  both  areas,  particularly  in  respect  of  land 
tenure, concessions, and preserving the rights of traditional land users to the forest resource. 
 
J. 

Conditions Attached to the Loan 

19.  Most  conditions  for  the  Project  relate  to  subproject  identification  and  have  been 
incorporated  in  the  selection  criteria.  The  Project  is  intended  to  have  national  impact  through 
policy  development  in  respect  of  land  tenure,  issuance  of  land  concessions,  incorporation  of 
safeguards, and more rigor in investment appraisal. It will also influence the protection of user 
rights on traditional upland farming areas. In addition, it will develop awareness of the need for 
safeguards  (through 
technical  assistance)  when 
considering  proposed  investments.  The  criteria  for  subprojects  will  ensure  that  these  aspects 
are considered in the selection process (Appendix 5 and Supplementary Appendix C) and are 
confirmed in the loan conditions. 
 
K. 

Economic Analysis of Representative Subprojects 

the  associated  capacity  development 

20. 
Two representative subprojects were analyzed to determine their suitability for funding. 
Each subproject demonstrated EIRRs in excess of 12%, ranging from 19.3% to 23.5% based on 
the identified net benefit flows. In each case, additional benefits from the investment could not 
be readily quantified and estimates were considered conservative. Sensitivity tests were carried 
out  to  the  main  potential  variables  that  might  affect  the  findings,  including  price  declines, 
increases  in  capital  costs,  and  a  reduction  in  utilization.  Sensitivity  to  routine  and  periodic 
maintenance  was  also  analyzed,  with  utilization  declining  to  pre-rehabilitation  levels  after  the 
maintenance ceased. In most cases, the benefits were not sensitive to changes in price levels 
or  to  increases  in  unit  investment  costs.  The  area  of  greatest  sensitivity  was  identified  from 
maintenance  practices.  Where  the  maintenance  ceased  after  5  years  of  operation,  the  EIRRs 
fell  dramatically  below  the  cost  of  capital.  In  cases  where  the  maintenance  ceased  10  years 
after  completion,  the  EIRRs  were  significantly  reduced  but  not  below  zero,  as  most  of  the 
benefits  would  have  been  received  before  deterioration  of  the  infrastructure.  The  economic 
benefit from subproject investments will, because of the selection criteria used, be higher than 
the  opportunity  cost  of  capital  and  constitute  sound  economic  investments  without  negative 
social and environmental impacts.
